3. Dr. Enkhzul Jargal, 50, oversees the Bayanzurkh Medical Center. Her office is wallpapered with animals to put sick children at ease.

4.  A chimney in one ger sends the coal smoke out through the opening in the roof. In the past 20 years, 600,000 people have migrated to Ulaanbaatar — many occupying traditional gers off the city's electric grid. They burn raw coal, garbage and other material to stay warm. Smokestacks feed a layer of smog that blankets the city.

5. The ger district is unplanned, lacking basic infrastructure. One-third of households live below the poverty line. The sign affixed to the fence says the family is willing to purchase a low-emission stove.

In 2001 Angie & Dan Bastian started making kettle corn in their garage... 16 years later they sold BOOMCHICKAPOP for $250 million. Tap the link in our bio to hear the incredible evolution of their partnership and their business. 🍿 (Image: @marenbruin | Maren Bruin for NPR)

Victoria Gray, 34, of Forest, Miss., is the first U.S. patient to be treated for a genetic disorder using the gene-editing tool called CRISPR. Gray has sickle cell disease which is caused by a genetic defect that causes bone marrow to create red blood cells that are sickle-shaped, hard and sticky. The deformed cells get stuck inside blood vessels and don't carry oxygen normally, causing a host of debilitating and, often, eventually life-shortening complications. It affects about 100,000 in the U.S., mostly African Americans. Millions more are affected worldwide. "It's a good time to get healed," Gray says in an exclusive interview with NPR. Click the link in our bio for the full story. (Image: @mererizzo | Meredith Rizzo/NPR)

Mongolia's herders are accustomed to cold, but the extreme conditions of the country's terrible winters, known as dzuds, killed countless livestock and livelihoods. Herders have had to adapt. Follow the link in our bio for the full story. (Images: @claireeclaire | Claire Harbage/NPR)

1. The sun sets on Baatarsuren Damdinbazar's pasture. The 45-year-old herder took a break from watching televised wrestling to feed dough to his goats and sheep.
2. Nergui and Tumurchudur "Tumee" Galsanjamts, 43, met in a hospital after Nergui had fallen off a horse and broken his leg. Tumurchudur was visiting another patient. They married in 1997.
3. Wearing a deel, a traditional Mongolian overcoat, Nergui feeds his sheep and goats, whose hooves kick up dust in the fading light.
4. Buddhist monk Banzragch Purevsuren comforted herders affected by the 2009-2010 dzud by reading from Buddhist texts. He joined government officials in making home visits. "Herders are hardworking," he says. "They can survive."

A few years ago, Jason Carney came across a statistic that took him by surprise. In its 2015 survey of jobs in the solar industry, the nonprofit Solar Foundation reported that 0.0% of solar workers in the state of Tennessee were black or African American. That number caught Carney's eye because the Nashville native is African American — and was working there as a solar installer in 2015. In fact, he was starting to design a solar array for his own home in north Nashville. Clearly, there had been an undercount. But, he thought, maybe not by much. Throughout his career, Carney, 39, has frequently been the only person of color in the room. It was true when he worked in the heating and cooling industry, and it remained true as his professional path led him into green building work and solar design. Follow the link in our bio for the full story. (Image: @tamarareynoldsphotography | Tamara Reynolds for NPR)

Roughly 9 million children — nearly 1 in 5 public school students in the U.S. — attend schools that are racially isolated and receive far less money than schools just a few miles away. That's according to a sweeping new review of the nation's most divisive school district borders from EdBuild, a nonprofit that investigates school funding inequities. "Inequality is endemic" in America's public schools, the report says, identifying nearly 1,000 school district borders where schools on one side receive at least 10% less money per student than schools on the other side and where the racial makeup of the two sides' students varies by 25 percentage points or more. It is the story of segregation, in 2019. (Image: @yasminegateau | Yasmine Gateau for NPR)

About 95% of 12-year-olds in the Philippines have tooth decay or cavities. And cavities affect 7 in 10 children in India, one-third of Tanzania teens and nearly 1 in every 3 Brazilians. These and other startling oral health statistics are the focus of a two-part series in The Lancet. In it, more than a dozen dentists and public health experts call for radical action to end neglected and widespread oral disease. The Lancet study authors also point at what they call a failed dental system, where many dentists prioritize treatment over prevention efforts — like toothbrushing with fluoride and restricting sugar intake. Coupled with an overwhelming number of sweetened food and beverage options, cavities are on the rise, especially in low- and middle-income countries. Here, roadside dentist Ram Ji learned his trade from his father — and says he's trained 29 street dentists in Varanasi, India. He believes that sweets are the main cause of the tooth decay he treats. (Images: @johnstanmeyer | John Stanmeyer for NPR)

The Apollo program spurred a technological revolution. 50 years later, a lot of that tech has trickled down to the public. From spring tires to firefighting suits, click the link in our bio for 6 bonafide space program spinoffs. Illustrations by @lilypadula | Lily Padula for NPR

1. Freeze-dried foods were perfect for the weight-conscious Apollo missions, in which the spacecraft needed to stay lean enough to get to the moon and back even as the astronauts consumed a hearty 2,800 calories per day. A favorite? Shrimp cocktails.

2. Apollo engineers outfitted the Lunar Roving Vehicle with airless tires made of springy, woven steel wire that were much like guitar or piano string. Years later scientists are looking at future applications for these durable wheels including earth tires that never go flat.

3. After three astronauts were killed in the Apollo 1 fire on Jan. 27, 1967, NASA was left scrambling to try to figure out how to make everything in the command module less flammable, including what the astronauts were wearing. It found what was needed in polybenzimidazole, or PBI, a heat-resistant material developed by Dr. Carl Shipp Marvel. Firefighting suits that contain PBI are one main market for the material now.

What kind of person are you? 
That's the question that a personality test called the Big Five seeks to answer. You respond to a series of statements about yourself – everything from "I have a kind word for everyone" to "I get chores done right away" – by agreeing, disagreeing or being neutral. Your final score gauges you on a quintet of characteristics: openness, conscientiousness, agreeableness, extroversion and neuroticism. 
The Big Five test began in the United States and then spread to Europe. It's commonly used in what are known as WEIRD countries, an acronym that stands for "Western Educated Industrialized Rich Developed." But in a new study published in July in Science Advances, the authors found out that something weird is going on with the test in non-WEIRD countries. They found that the test wasn't always a reliable measure of personality traits in these places. 
Illustration by @MalakaGharib | Malaka Gharib/NPR

For decades, the Indian government has been conducting a special census in Assam, called the National Register of Citizens (NRC), to try to figure out who is a valid Indian citizen — and who might be an undocumented migrant. A char is a river island formed by silt carried downriver. Chars rise up and are submerged every few years. Every time a char erodes, the people living there dismantle their homes and move to the next-closest char by boat. They can't afford to move to the mainland. Many of those living on the chars of lower Assam are Muslims of Bengali origin. Their lives keep shifting like the islands they live on. Assam borders Bangladesh and has long been home to migrants from there. Last year, the state government issued a draft NRC list, and some 4 million people living in Assam who thought they were Indian citizens were left off. Tap the link in our bio for the full story. (Images: @cknotok | CK Vijayakumar for NPR)

1. A young man living on a small river island known as a char heads out to catch a boat and cross the Brahmaputra River to the mainland, in Assam's Barpeta district. 
2. Houses on a char are built on higher ground to avoid flooding. 
3. Soleman Nessa's husband took his own life after authorities questioned his citizenship. 
4. Nasir Uddin, 29, is the informal leader of the Chandanpur char. His mother and both sisters were left off the NRC.
5. Young men fish in the Brahmaputra River. The river serves as a source of livelihood and transportation, but when it floods, it is also a source of destruction.
6. A one-room school in Chandanpur char.

A record number of honeybee colonies died last winter.

According to the Bee Informed Partnership's latest survey, released last month, U.S. beekeepers lost nearly 40% of their honeybee colonies last winter — the greatest reported winter hive loss since the partnership started its surveys 13 years ago.

Find out why at the link in our bio. (Images: @livfalcigno | Olivia Falcigno for NPR)

At some point in our lives, many of us realize that the way we hear our own voice isn't the way others hear us. And we begin to realize that our voices communicate so much more than mere information: they reveal our feelings, our temperament, our identity. (Image: @hisiheyah | Angela Hsieh/NPR)

🌕 50 years ago, Apollo astronauts collected their first moon rocks. Those samples are still being studied to mine lunar secrets and scientists are hoping to get access to more of them soon. Dr. Darby Dyar is one of the lucky scientists picked to study an Apollo sample that has never been unsealed. Tap the link in our bio for the full story. (Images: @kierankesner | Kieran Kesner for NPR and NASA)

1. From 1969 through 1972, Apollo astronauts brought back 842 pounds of lunar samples, including core samples and rocks. Shown here is Apollo 11 lunar sample 10071,0.

2. Dyar in her office at Mount Holyoke College in Massachusetts. She recalls the first time she handled moon rocks collected by the Apollo astronauts: "I remember my hands shaking." 3. Apollo 12 astronaut Alan Bean holds a sample container filled with lunar soil.

4. Apollo 17 astronauts Eugene Cernan and Harrison Schmitt work on the lunar surface.

5. (Left) Darby Dyar observes various samples taken from the moon, some as small as grains of sand, which all have to be returned to NASA after Dyar finishes studying them at her lab. (Right) A moon rock as seen under the microscope.

This week as President Trump faced controversy, the re-election campaign launched its initiative to reach women voters in 2020. The event was held in the Philadelphia suburbs, an area where women were decisive in electing Democrats to Congress in 2018. (Images: @hanloveyoon | Hannah Yoon for NPR)

1. Women take a selfie during the Women for Trump kickoff event.

2. Trump adviser Kimberly Guilfoyle invoked young progressive Democrats, like New York's Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez, in firing up the crowd.

3. Ginger Howard, Republican National Committeewoman for Georgia, shows off her red elephant printed shirt at the event.

4. A woman holds a Trump 2020 sign in the crowd.

5. Barbara Stinson, from Harlem N.Y., shows off her Trump buttons.

A wall titled "Who's The Next To Drop Out?" with faces of the Democratic candidates running for president in the 2020 election is displayed during the Netroots Nation conference at the Pennsylvania Convention Center in Philadelphia. Progressives say this word "electability" is being used as a fear tactic to intimidate voters into choosing a moderate, centrist nominee, specifically, former Vice President Joe Biden. But many of the activists who gathered over the weekend at the Netroots Nation conference insisted that's a foolish strategy. Biden, who has consistently led in early polling, is potentially the worst option for the party, they say, warning that Democrats could repeat the mistakes of 2016. (Image: @nataliepiserchio | Natalie Piserchio for NPR)

For most of us, the photos brought back by Apollo 11 are iconic and a little difficult to comprehend. But for astronauts, they represent something more: hours of training, risks taken and the many people on the ground who worked to make the journey possible.

NPR’s @rjckseen spoke to five former NASA astronauts who flew on space missions to learn how they see these photos. Tap the link in our bio for the full story. (Images: NASA)

1. “Wearing a spacesuit is not the most comfortable thing. You kind of have to learn to work with the suit rather than fight it. But it's still a very physical activity. You get bruises and hot spots and things like that.” - Leroy Chiao 
2. “If things are going normal you're along for the ride until it puts you into orbit. The main thing that you're feeling is, 'For heaven's sake don't let me screw up if something goes wrong.” - Russell Schweickart 
3. “When I see this, I think of leaving the airlock to do a spacewalk. For me it was kind of like being at an aquarium saying, 'look there is all the pretty fish' versus being a scuba diver. You're no longer looking at the pretty fish in the aquarium, you're a scuba diver interacting with that environment. You really are a spaceman, or in this case you are really becoming a moon man.” - Mike Massimino 
4. “I mean, it's an ugly beast. But for us, it was beautiful. It was just incredible.” - Schweickart 
5. “When I look at [this] 'Earthrise' picture, one of my first thoughts is I am so glad that they took a picture. You know there's the mission itself. I mean just to get there, accomplish the actual objective, and get home safely is enough to ask of any human being. If you don't bring back pictures like this one, people are not going to be able to feel what it was like to be there.” - Catherine Coleman 
6. “On any given day during the shuttle era, we might have someone who really had a difficult time getting down the ladder on their own. So, I can only imagine what it was like for [the Apollo 11 crew] to try to deal with bobbing up and down as if they were a cork and then getting into a life raft waiting for a helicopter to come.” - Charles Bolden

A whiff of lavender changed Susan Griffin-Black's life (truly), and just a few years later the  body care company, EO Products, was born. Hear how she and co-founder Brad Black kept the business strong even after their divorce. (Image: @chelseabeck.psd | Chelsea Beck for NPR)

Fifty years after the Saturn V rocket carried the astronauts to the moon, the Smithsonian National Air and Space Museum is honoring the historic mission with a giant projection on the Washington Monument. Follow the link in our bio for more photos. (Image: @shuranhuang | Shuran Huang/NPR) #nprpictureshow

At a Border Patrol holding facility in El Paso, Texas, an agent told a Honduran family that one parent would be sent to Mexico while the other parent and their three children could stay in the United States, according to the family. The agent turned to the couple's youngest daughter — 3-year-old Sofia, whom they call Sofi — and asked her to make a choice. "The agent asked her who she wanted to go with, mom or dad," her mother, Tania, told NPR through an interpreter. "And the girl, because she is more attached to me, she said mom. But when they started to take [my husband] away, the girl started to cry. The officer said, 'You said [you want to go] with mom.' "

Tania and her husband, Joseph, said they spent parts of two days last week trying to prevent the Border Patrol from separating their family. They were aided by a doctor who had examined Sofi and pleaded with agents not to separate the family, Joseph and Tania said. [NPR is not using migrants' last names in this story because these are people who are in the middle of immigration proceedings.] (images @claireeclaire | Claire Harbage/NPR 
1. Tania and Joseph's 3-year-old daughter, Sofia, plays with a car in the shade at a shelter in Juárez, Mexico, last week. Sofia has a serious heart condition and had a heart attack.
2. Tania and Joseph said they spent parts of two days last week trying to prevent the Border Patrol from separating their family.
3. Sofi's 6-year-old brother plays with other children at a shelter in Juárez last week.

Look at a picture of the Apollo 11 launch and you'll probably notice the rocket's pointed tip and the fire coming from the five giant engines in the first stage of the 36-story-tall Saturn V rocket. What you might miss is arguably the most important part of the entire thing: the command module. It's the tiny, gumdrop-shaped vehicle sitting just below the tip. It holds the astronauts, their clothing, sleeping bags, food and — along with a companion service module — all of the systems needed for a round-trip journey to the moon. It's also the only piece of the spacecraft to complete the entire trip and splash down back on Earth. Click the link in our bio to hear from two engineers who helped make it happen.

1. The Apollo 11 command/service module orbits the moon. (Image: NASA)

2. The Apollo 11 Saturn V space vehicle lifts off. (Image: NASA)

3. The command module is loaded aboard a Super Guppy Aircraft at Ellington Air Force Base after returning to earth. (Image: NASA)

4. Chuck Lowry (left) an expert in parachutes, which were vital for slowing the command module's descent as it returned to Earth, reviews designs on a drafting board with Carlos Moore and Kel Shaw (right). (Image: Courtesy of Chuck Lowry)

5. Lowry adjusts a cap commemorating the 50th anniversary of Apollo 11. (Image: Michael Hernandez)
6. Gerald Blackburn was only 19 when he started on the project as a lab technician, testing and inspecting hardware. "You got to the point where you began to realize that this thing was so complex. It was so big that there was no way you could fathom the whole program," he said. "So you had to rely on everybody who was doing their job and taking care of what they needed to take care of." (Image: Michael Hernandez)

7. The Apollo 11 command module returned to earth on July 24, 1969. A helicopter hovers over the inverted command module shortly after splashdown. (Image: NASA) 
8. The command module is lowered on to the deck of the U.S.S. Hornet. (Image: NASA)

Last month, photographer Cayla Nimmo documented the scenes of Diné Pride in Window Rock, Ariz. The festivities were in the shadow of the Navajo Nation's same-sex marriage ban. Follow the link in our bio for the full story. (Images: @caynimm | Cayla Nimmo for NPR) #nprpictureshow

1. Geronimo Louie dances in a rainbow-themed shawl in front of the Window Rock park at Diné Pride. Half Navajo and half Apache, Louie spoke about the experience coming out as gay within those two cultures.

2. Alray Nelson (left) joins Arlando Teller in a livestream from Diné Pride. Nelson is the founder of Diné Equality and co-founder of Diné Pride, while Teller is the Arizona state representative for District 7.

3. Matthew Slick is silhouetted by the purple light as the Navajo Council Chamber is lit in rainbow colors for Pride on June 28 in Window Rock, Ariz., the capital of the Navajo Nation.

4. Ophelia Shondee (left) and Bonnie Gillespie kiss during their marriage ceremony at Diné Pride. Same-sex marriage is illegal through Navajo courts, so the couple, who have been together for 13 years, had to get their marriage license through an Arizona court, outside the reservation.

5. Mattee Jim, master of ceremonies for Diné Pride, waiting inside Navajo Nation Council chamber in her sequin panda outfit waiting to be introduced.

Your friends want to help you out when there's a family health crisis. But it can be overwhelming to manage the offers of support. Here's advice to help friends help you. Follow the link in our bio for the full essay. (Image: @minnie_phan | Minnie Phan for NPR)

Club music is often grounded in bass and rhythm, but electronic and dance songs that feature wind instruments explore innovation as well as connections with histories of jazz and indigenous music.

Follow the link in our bio for the full essay. (Image: @hisiheyah | Angela Hsieh/NPR)

Manisha Jaisi, 16, poses at the shed outside her house in Nepal where she sleeps when she has her period. Jaisi got her period two months after her neighbor, Dambara Upadhyay, died of unknown causes while sleeping in a similar shed in 2016. Jaisi says she never goes without her phone in the shed because she's scared after Upadhyay's death. Follow the link in our bio for more. (Image: Sajana Shrestha for NPR)

"Does law enforcement, or more importantly larger society, view black men with firearms in a certain way? Let's have that discussion," says Philip Smith, president and founder of the National African American Gun Association. The organization's goal is to introduce black Americans to guns and also instruct them on how to use them. Some in the group say it's time to have a larger platform. Follow the link in our bio for the full story. (Image: Lynsey Weatherspoon for NPR)

Going to a doctor who puts you at ease can actually improve your health. We have six tips for finding a primary care doctor you click with — and how you can make the most out of that relationship. 
1. Figure out what type of patient you are, and let that guide your choice of doctor.
2. Seek out a doctor who makes you feel comfortable — and trust your gut on this one.
3. When you go to the doctor, go prepared.
4. Be clear about your agenda from the beginning, because your doctor's agenda may be different from yours.
5. Don't be afraid to be yourself at the doctor's office.
6. You have a right to give your doctor feedback. But if things aren't working, don't be afraid to break up. 
Follow the link in our bio for the full episode from NPR’s Life Kit. (Illustration: @shannondrewthis | Shannon Wright for NPR)

Meet the Azalea Trail Maids. They're the embodiment of old school Southern hospitality with a modern twist. To get the honor, girls need to have impressive resumes, such as being valedictorians, National Merit Scholarship winners and even in ROTC. ⁣⁣
⁣⁣
The selective process and preparation is meant for them to become ambassadors of Mobile, Ala. Once chosen, they represent the town for a year and wear 50 pound dresses, which can cost up to $6,000, to smile, wave and have their photo taken. ⁣⁣
⁣⁣
Click the link in our bio to read what changed about the group over the past 50 years. ⁣
⁣
(Images: @adairrutledge | Adair Freeman Rutledge) #nprpictureshow

Tania and Joseph fled violence in Honduras and lived for months in shelters in Juárez, Mexico with their two young daughters and son, waiting for their time in U.S. immigration court. They say they were threatened three times in Juárez, a city dominated by violent drug cartels. NPR is not using migrants' last names in this story because these are people who are in the middle of immigration proceedings.

Their youngest daughter, 3-year-old has a scar on her chest from heart surgery. In court, Linda Rivas, executive director of Las Americas Immigrant Advocacy Center, tried to get Tania and her family taken out of Migrant Protection Protocols because of the daughter's heart condition. Rivas later said she expected the family to be returned to Mexico. Immigration Judge Nathan Herbert set the family's next hearing for Aug. 15, when Rivas will begin presenting their asylum case. Follow the link in our bio for the full story. (Images: @claireeclaire | Claire Harbage/NPR)

1. Tania and Joseph's 3-year-old daughter has a scar on her chest from heart surgery. 
2. Tania and Joseph stand in the kitchen of the space they are sharing with other migrants at a shelter in Juárez, Mexico.
3. People cross the Paso del Norte International Bridge in the morning on their way to the U.S. Migrants with scheduled court hearings cross the bridge before being taken into custody and transported to court.
4. Linda Rivas sits outside the Richard C. White Federal Building in El Paso, Texas.

The District of Columbia is leading the way on a new restorative justice program in which young offenders get a second chance. It's difficult, but authorities say it's worth it. Follow the link in our bio for the full story. (Image: @ankegladnick | Anke Gladnick for NPR)

For some migrants in Juárez, Mexico, waiting for their asylum claims to be processed means staying in a hot, crowded hotel basement and embarking on a process marked by confusion. (Images: @claireeclaire | Claire Harbage/NPR)

1. Grisélida holds a plastic bag of documents from U.S. immigration authorities. She and her 12-year-old son Julio fled their home in Honduras when a gang began recruiting him.

2. Mattresses line the floor of a hotel basement in Juárez, where migrants are waiting to enter the U.S. Many crossed the border and were then returned to Mexico as part of the "Remain in Mexico" policy.

3. Gilmer, 23, and Glendi, 21, sit on stairs in the hotel basement with their 3-year-old daughter. They left Guatemala seeking a better life for their daughter, but have been staying in the basement for two months.

4. One man staying in the hotel basement holds out his number in line for entering the U.S. One Mexican official said about 100 numbers are called every day, depending on capacity.

In humans, a preference for helping shows up very early in life. Kiley Hamlin is an associate professor of psychology at the University of British Columbia, and she has used puppets to test this preference in babies. Hamlin had infants watch as a puppet looked longingly up a hill it wanted to climb. When the puppet tried, though, one of two things happened: Either a helper puppet gave the climber a boost up the hill or, once at the top, the climber puppet got bumped back down by a hinderer puppet. Hamlin then put the helper and hinderer in front of the babies and waited to see which one they preferred. "The surprising thing was the sheer number of babies who were showing this preference for the helper," says Hamlin. (Image: @lhrybyk | Laurent Hrybyk for NPR)

Nomehí, a 24-year-old migrant from Honduras, was separated from her 15-year-old brother at the time they crossed the U.S.-Mexico border. He has been reunited with their mother, while she feels stuck at a migrant shelter in Mexico. 
Among the migrants arriving at the U.S.-Mexico border are extended family members with children in tow, hoping to give them a better life. But many of them may never join those children in the U.S. Follow the link in our bio for the full story. (Image: @paulratje | Paul Ratje for NPR)

Photographer Amrita Chandradas, an Indian Tamil who was born and raised in Singapore, traveled to Jaffna, Sri Lanka to document disappearances among Sri Lankan Tamils. 
1. "I am keeping this carefully for our only son, who may never get to know his father's love anytime soon." —Sudarshini, whose husband disappeared in 2006
2. "We sleep with light on because we are afraid without male presence two of us will be taken advantage of at night — and it would not be the first time," Malar, 41, whose husband went missing in 2006, says of herself and her daughter, Shalini.
3. "Seeing my friends talk about my father, or when I saw their fathers pick them up from school, it is heartbreaking. He was a good father, a really good father. I miss him." —Shalini, 16
4. Kuneswary looked in every camp for her son. He was the sole breadwinner of the house, working as a fisherman.
5. Sudarshini works outside the kitchen where she and her husband would often cook together before he disappeared. "He is alive," she says.
6. Navaratharasa holds his grandchild at the seaside where he used to bring his child Sathees Kumar, who disappeared in 1996.
7. "They dragged him away like this," the father of Nagulesan Naguraja says while demonstrating how the military took his son away.
8. Delft Island, called Neduntheevu by Tamils.
9. Sargunarasa went missing with his neighbor Seliyyah on July 5, 2006, while on a business trip. His wife, Malar, and Shalini, their only daughter, hold his passport image.

Aden Batar, 52, fled the civil war in Somalia for the U.S. in 1994. Now, he directs a refugee resettlement program in Utah –– the same program that helped resettle his family 25 years ago. "I lived in this community close to half of my life," Aden says to his son, Jamal. "You were 2 years old when you came here. So, I want people to look at us as human beings, who went through a lot and survived." Follow the link in our bio for the full story. (Image: Mia Warren/StoryCorps)

After 15 years in and out of prison Dave Dahl returned to the family bakery. He developed a new kind of bread – organic, nutty, and a little sweet. 
In 2015 Dave's Killer Bread sold for $275 million. But there's a LOT more to the story. Follow the link in our bio to hear the full episode. (Image: @suzanne__dias | Suzanne Dias for NPR)

In his new book, ‘For the Good of the Game,’ former Major League Baseball commissioner Bud Selig is candid offers a stark contrast to his public persona when he led the sport for 22 years. NPR spent an afternoon with Selig as he watched a Milwaukee Brewers game. (Images: @sarastathas | Sara Stathas for NPR)

Emotional outbursts. Lost sleep. These are signs that your kids are spending too much time with digital devices. Here's what you can do about it. 
Here's what to remember: - Pay attention to your children's emotional relationship with screens, not just how much time they are spending with them. - Don't just make technology rules based on time. - Do guard bedtimes and mealtimes. - Don't expect taking away the phone to solve all your family's problems. - Mentor your kids; don't just monitor them. (Image: @jasjyotjasjyot | Jasjyot Singh Hans for NPR)

The National Independence Day Parade in Washington, D.C. kicked off the July 4th festivities in the nation’s capital. WAMU photographer Tyrone Turner said the parade was very different than he was expecting with the diversity of cultures in the parade. (Images: @tyronefoto | Tyrone Turner/WAMU for NPR) #nprpictureshow

A 19-year-old woman talks with nurse Valeria Zafisoa at a traveling contraception clinic in eastern Madagascar run by the British nonprofit group Marie Stopes International. A new study in the medical journal The Lancet suggests that the so-called Mexico City policy, a Republican-led policy that cuts U.S. funding to programs that "perform or promote abortion," has actually increased the rate of abortions by about 40% in the countries studied — likely because the funding ban caused a reduction in access to contraception and a consequent rise in unwanted pregnancies. Follow the link in our bio for the full story. (Image: @samreinders | Samantha Reinders for NPR)

Last month, NPR asked our audience to share memories of summer in the form of a haiku. 
More than 4,000 people responded with musings about tasty treats, summer loving and wild adventures — all in just 17 syllables. 
Cotton candy smiles 
and merry go round horses 
in soft sudden rain —Cindy Guentherman, Loves Park, Ill. 
Follow the link in our bio for more haiku. (Image: @scottbakal | Scott Bakal for NPR)

More than 6,000 migrants who came to the United States to ask for asylum have been sent back to Ciudad Juárez, Mexico, just across the border from El Paso, to wait for their day in U.S. immigration court under the "Remain in Mexico" program. But only about 20 of them have lawyers, according to human rights groups and attorneys who work with the migrants. Above: Members of Mexico's National Guard and Federal Police patrol the U.S.-Mexico border to prevent migrants from crossing into the U.S. from Ciudad Juárez. Residents and officials say they've never before seen such a deployment on the northern border. (Image @paulratje | Paul Ratje for NPR)

"Sex for fish." That unlikely phrase is used in some lakefront communities in sub-Saharan Africa and other parts of the world where men catch the fish and women sell the catch to local customers. In Malawi, for instance, a woman may take a fisherman's catch and promise to pay him once she's made her sales. Only she might have trouble selling all the fish. So she might pay off what she owes for the fish by engaging in a sexual encounter. (Images: @juliagunther_photography | Julia Gunther) 
1. A fisherman's boat makes its way across Lake Chilwa in Malawi. A large portion of Lake Chilwa dries out every year, and the fishing industry disappears along with it. Most fishermen then head to Lake Malawi, where there is fishing year-round. 
2. A crowd of fish traders forms around a boat at Lake Malawi laden with usipa, a species of small sardine-like fish that are dried and sold all over the country. 
3. A fisherman holds up a chambo — what locals call a type of tilapia native to Lake Malawi. Chambo is one of Malawi's most popular fish. Once it was plentiful, but now it is listed as "critically endangered" because of overfishing. 
4. Chrissy Masala in her hairdressing salon in Mpyupyu, Malawi. For five years, Masala says she would have sex with fisherman and be paid with fish, which she would sell at local markets and big cities. But she felt that the community disapproved. Eventually, she saved enough money to open the salon in 2013. 
5. Catherine Kambanje with her 1-year-old son, photographed in the village of Kachulu on Lake Chilwa in Malawi. She says she traded sex for fish for seven years. Typical payment was a bucket of fish. She'd use some to feed her family and sell the rest. Now she burns wood to make charcoal, which she sells. She says she earns significantly less than she did before. 
6. Fisherman Mekius Dominic stands in Lake Malawi. Dominic became a fisherman three years ago. He says he has never engaged in transactional sex but knows plenty of men who do. "My friends have said to me that I must do it. They force me to come with them and drink beer. Then they tell me I have to have sex with a woman there. But I do not do it."

According to the facial feedback hypothesis, the simple act of putting a smile on your face can boost your mood. But recent research shows pasting on a grin can have mixed results. Follow the link in our bio for the full story. (Image: @pmvickers | Paige Vickers for NPR)

Although China officially decriminalized homosexuality in 1997, activists say the stigma around being LGBTQ — and discussing it publicly — remains today. Over the course of five years, Italian-born photographer Raul Ariano, @raulariano, fulfilled his goal to "share stories of love, dignity and hope in a segment of society that tends to be hidden in China." Inspired by Hong Kong filmmaker Wong Kar-wai's 1997 movie Happy Together, he photographed participants in their apartments, with natural lighting and different colors to show the intimacy between couples. #nprpictureshow 1. Zhongbao and Zhiyong in Shenyang.
2. Leanna and Xiaoguo in Beijing.
3. Dan Dan in in Shanghai. He has moved from a small city in Guangdong province to feel free from his traditional family. He wishes to come out with his parents, but he's afraid of their reaction. 4. Perry and Selina in Shanghai. 6. Shawn and Anson met in a rented apartment, as Shawn lives in a distant dormitory and Anson lives and studies in Wenzhou. 7. Wan Wan and his boyfriend. 8. Renais and Zheng in Shanghai. 9. Weishan and Shiyu in Shanghai. Bottom: Shawn and Anson. 10. Perry and Selina in Shanghai.

Americans bought tens of millions of pairs of eclipse glasses to watch the total solar eclipse that crossed the U.S. in 2017. Now tens of thousands of them are heading for South America for another eclipse on July 2.

Astronomers Without Borders has sent 40,000 repurposed glasses to Argentina, Chile and Peru, which are being distributed at schools, universities and planetariums for this upcoming eclipse.

The group plans to continue to send batches of the glasses it collected to other countries for use during future eclipses, including another total eclipse next year in South America. Follow the link in our bio for more! (Photo by NPR)

They're early risers and hard workers. Some are the first in their family to attend college. Often they struggle to pay rent. And that means working while taking classes. Meet the "nontraditional" college students of today:

1. “Being first-gen, just getting to college itself is a challenge because you don't know how to prepare for it," says Diana Platas. As a DREAMer, she couldn’t apply for federal financial aid. But a scholarship helped her afford college. Now a graduate, she hopes to go on to study law. (Image: Loren Elliott for NPR)

2. Evan Spencer worked at a restaurant after graduating from high school. He used the money he made to pay for classes at his community college. "It can be a painful process to grow and to learn," he says, "when you're in class with an 18-year-old ... you can see the person you used to be." (Image: Elissa Nadworny/NPR)

3. "I want more because I've lived through it: I know what it's like to be homeless." Eric Ramos is the first in his family to graduate from high school. While taking college courses, he works to help his mom pay for rent and groceries. (Image: Camille Phillips/Texas Public Radio)

Follow the link in our bio for the full story.

Why We Remember Stonewall: An Illustrated History. The Stonewall Inn is a sacred place for many in the LGBTQ community. Fifty years ago, a raid and series of riots outside the New York City bar helped launch a civil rights movement. LA Johnson illustrates the story of Stonewall and its aftermath in 10 frames. Link in bio for the full story. (Credit: @neoncatdc | LA Johnson/NPR)

A family that plays video games together stays together. Experts say that when parents become digital mentors, children can learn empathy and resilience and prepare for careers. Learn more about the bright side of screen time through our link in bio. (Image: Ryan Johnson for NPR)

"Curiosity about the sober life is trending. Scientists say cutting out alcohol can improve your sleep and blood pressure, and help your liver. Follow the link in our bio for the full story. (Images: @juliarphoto | Julia Robinson for NPR)  1. Some who have given up booze altogether join ""sober sometimes"" friends to enjoy nonalcoholic drinks at Sans Bar in Austin, Texas.  2. Chris Marshall is a certified substance abuse counselor and the founder of Sans Bar, a venue for ""the nightlife experience"" without the alcohol, in Austin. He has been sober for the past 12 years.  3. The proliferation of craft mocktails made with nonalcoholic distilled spirits is making it easier and more fun for people who abstain from alcohol to feel like they are still part of the party."

Daisha Smith, 24, was sued by Mary Washington Hospital in Fredericksburg, Virginia for an unpaid medical bill — a bill she didn't know she owed until her wages started disappearing out of her paycheck. Not every hospital sues over unpaid bills, but a few sue a lot. In Virginia, 36% of hospitals sued patients and garnished their wages in 2017, according to a study published Tuesday in the American Medical Association's journal, JAMA. Follow the link in our bio for the full story. (Image: @livfalcigno | Olivia Falcigno/NPR)

Cattleman Will Harris and solar power company Silicon Ranch are putting together a plan to rotate animal species around a new solar farm in southwest Georgia. The animals would graze on grass and weeds and naturally fertilize the land with their manure. In between grazing periods, the land would have time to recover. Grazing in this way could prevent erosion and, down the road, potentially sequester carbon in the soil, as Harris has achieved on his own land. Follow the link in our bio for the full story. (Image: @johnathonkelso | Johnathon Kelso for NPR)

Nonprofits and advocacy groups use international rankings as a tool to name and shame countries into improving their policies. But the indexes do have some drawbacks. Follow the link in our bio for the full story. (Image: @leifparsons Leif Parsons for NPR)

William Portwood, who died less than two weeks after NPR confirmed his involvement in the 1965 murder of Boston minister James Reeb, poses for a photograph in front of his home in Selma, Ala. (image: Chip Brantley/NPR)

Having to come up with $1,000 unexpectedly can be a challenge for anyone. NPR's recent poll on rural health found that especially true for one group: people with disabilities. (Image: @kim.ryu | Kim Ryu for NPR)

In 1998, Ichard Oden committed a crime that got him sent away for two decades. He was 19. He got out of prison in February. Today, he's a 40-year-old man with very little job experience. 
As it turns out, Oden is coming back into society at a time when the economy is booming and attitudes toward people with criminal records are changing. Many employers say they can't find enough workers. And for Oden and 20 million or so Americans with a felony record, that might mean a much better shot at getting a job and reintegrating into society. A week after being released, Oden was hired by a construction company. Follow the link in our bio for the full story. (Image: @elaine_cromie | Elaine Cromie for NPR)

The small city of Hendersonville, N.C., recently celebrated LGBTQ pride for the first time. Unlike many pride celebrations in bigger cities, there was no parade or festival. It was a potluck picnic. Rev. Jerry Miller, whose son came out as gay four decades ago, was there with his wife, Bea.

Twenty years ago, Miller began leading a local PFLAG chapter, a group for family and friends of LGBTQ people. At first, it wasn't easy for him to reconcile his faith with his son's identity. "My wife and I basically went in the closet because I was a pastor of a Baptist church at that time. And I prayed that God would change my son someday," Miller says. "God didn't change him, he changed me." (Image: Monique LaBorde for NPR)

For decades, doctors and nurses from rich countries have flown to poor countries to perform surgery and provide other medical care not readily available. They stay for a limited period of time. Then they head back home. We wanted to hear from our readers: If you've been part of a fly-in mission, what was it like? What were the pros and cons? More than 75 medical workers responded to our callout. (Image: @itschrisnickels | Chris Nickels for NPR)

Last week, NPR’s Rough Translation took listeners deep inside a hostage rescue operation. After Iraqi photojournalist Kamaran Najm (pictured on the right) was kidnapped by ISIS, his family and friends were left to figure out how to save him. 
This week, Rough Translation brings you part two of the story. Listen as Kamaran’s search party uncovers new clues, sits down with ISIS and struggles to know who they can trust. Follow the link in our bio for the full podcast episode. (Image: Rebecca Bradshaw)

You've taken the leap and enrolled in college! But money issues don't end when you accept your financial aid. Paying your way through school can be stressful, but lots of folks have made it work and they have advice for how you, too, can navigate your years in college. Follow the link in our bio for the full Life Kit episode. (Image: @shannondrewthis | Shannon Wright for NPR)

Hal Herzog, a professor of psychology at Western Carolina University, says the more we attribute human-like qualities to animals, the more ethically problematic it may be to keep them as pets. Follow the link in our bio for the full story. (Image: @hisiheyah | Angela Hsieh/NPR)

When students are believed to be a danger to themselves or others, they're sometimes restrained in school, or isolated in a separate room. These practices, known as restraint and seclusion, are supposed to be a last resort, and they disproportionately affect boys and students with disabilities or special needs. Follow the link in our bio for the full story. (Image: @_samdraws | Sam Rowe for NPR)

Humans have made an indelible mark on the planet. Since the mid-20th century, we've accelerated the digging of mines, construction of dams, expansion of cities and clearing of forests for agriculture — activity that will be visible in the geological record for eons to come. 
Some scientists are calling it the Anthropocene era, or the age of the humans ("anthropos" is Greek for human). Photographer Edward Burtynsky and filmmakers Jennifer Baichwal and Nicholas de Pencier traveled to 22 countries to document the impact of humans on earth. 
1. In Nigeria's oil-rich Niger Delta, oil bunkering — the practice of siphoning oil from pipelines — has transformed parts of the once-thriving delta ecosystem into an ecological dead zone, according to the U.N. Environment Programme. 
2. This aerial photo depicts the sawmills of Lagos, Nigeria. The timber from the country's rainforests, some of the most heavily deforested in the world, are processed in this coastal city, polluting the lagoons.
3. The Dandora Landfill in Nairobi, Kenya is a sprawling 30-acre dump that grows by an average of 850 tons of solid waste a day, according to the U.N. Environment Programme. 
4. An underground potash mine in the Ural mountains of Russia. The potassium-rich salt is mined to produce fertilizer. The team says that the mine shows the impact of modernized agricultural practices that help feed Earth's 7.5 billion people. The spiraled pattern seen here is caused by the machines used to extract the salts.

Evangelicals have played an important role in modern day American politics – from supporting President Trump to helping elect Jimmy Carter back in 1976. How and when did this religious group become so intertwined with today's political issues? In this episode, what it means to be an evangelical today and how it has changed over time. Follow the link in our bio for the full story. (Image: @hisiheyah | Angela Hsieh/NPR)

The founding director of the National Museum of African American History and Culture, Lonnie Bunch has dedicated his life to telling a fuller, rounder and more complex historical narrative. He'll continue that mission in taking the reins of the entire Smithsonian Institution as its first African American secretary, overseeing 19 museums, 21 libraries and the National Zoo.(Image: @shuranhuang | Shuran Huang/NPR)

Take these books ... please?! The famous NPR Summer Reader Poll is back, and this year we're celebrating funny books. What makes you laugh — or giggle, or even just snicker quietly? We want to know! (Image: @hisiheyah | Angela Hsieh/NPR)

After his son's birth, Dirk Anschütz photographed fathers and sons for six years. In addition to producing a compelling body of work that helps showcase the expanding bounds of what fatherhood can look like, Anschütz says his "Fathers and Sons" project made him a more understanding dad. #FathersDay #nprpictureshow (Images: @dirkanschutz I Dirk Anschütz)

1. Caleb has a developmental disability and is largely nonverbal. When Matt, an actor, did his movement and acting exercises, he noticed that Caleb reacted strongly to them. They started doing them together, opening up a new way for father and son to communicate.

2. Isma is a musician from Equatorial Guinea and moved with his wife to Washington, D.C., where they had a son named Matteo. It wasn't easy for Isma to move to a new country, learn a new language and be a new dad all at the same time.

3. Yansen is a hip-hop dancer and actor. His siblings and his father, Hector, all worked in financial institutions. Yansen decided to go against the grain. Father and son both agree, though, that Yansen is pretty good at what he does.

4. Mike is the son of an American mom and an Italian dad and grew up in a little southern Italian town. He took a month of parental leave to take care of his newborn son Elliot.

5. Corey is an avid painter who worked as a prison guard and is now a school bus driver. When Isaiah was 13, he was mugged at gunpoint in Brooklyn. After that, his parents decided to move the family to the suburbs on Long Island. Isaiah liked his new high school and became an integral part of the football team before going to college.

6. Andrew and his wife work on film and TV productions. Because they have long workdays, it's hard for them to be home at the same time. As such, Andrew spends a lot of time alone with Homer.

7. John designs bars and restaurants and has a big workshop. When Roman has days off from school, he often joins his dad at the shop.

This week NPR’s Code Switch podcast tells the story of Hawaiians who pulled their language back from the brink while they were still learning how to speak it.

According to the Linguistic Society of America, “the fate of a language can be changed in a single generation if it is no longer being learned by children.” So, a handful of Hawaiians who learned to speak the language as adults decided to teach it to children. They opened a “Hawaiian only” pre-school that evolved into a K-12 public charter school that graduated its 20th class this year. (Images: @mirage_e | Shereen Marisol Meraji/NPR)

1. Kealiʻi Clark graduated from Ke Kula ‘O Nawahiokalani’opu’u in 2002. The school’s mission to bring the Hawaiian language back to Hawai’i. Clark now works at the school as a custodian.

2. Kalāmanamana Harman’s parents met studying Hawaiian in college. They decided to reclaim the language by raising their three children in a Hawaiian speaking home. She’s the first of her family in two generations to grow up speaking her native language.

3. Larry Kimura is now referred to as the “grandfather of the Hawaiian language revitalization movement.” Kimura has been teaching Hawaiian at the university level for half a century and founded the Punana Leo pre-school program.

4. Toddlers enrolled in the Pūnana Leo (pre-school) in Hilo.

5. A classroom at the Ke Kula 'O Nāwahīokalani'ōpuʻu K-12 public charter school in Hilo

6. 7th grader at Nāwahī, ʻĪhipainuʻu Peʻa, rehearsing in the gym for a Hula performance. Students study the Hawaiian language and cultural practices.

7. The Nāwahī school is connected to the University of Hawaii’s Ka Haka ʻUla O Keʻelikōlani (KHUOK) College of Hawaiian Language. Steven Kekoa Kalua, 22, graduated this year with a minor in Hawaiian studies. Today, in Hilo, it’s possible to go from pre-school through a PhD program entirely in Hawaiian.

Paying off student loans can be a financial nightmare. But if you know how to navigate the system, you can find a payment plan that's more affordable. Plus, if you qualify for loan forgiveness, you might get tens of thousands of dollars of debt wiped out. 
Here's what to remember: - Download a list of all your federal loans. - If you get an income-driven repayment plan, stay in it! - Don't trust your loan servicer. Do the research, find your payment plan and get it in writing. - Take a personal day or make a date with a friend to tackle student-loan paperwork. (Image: @neoncatdc | LA Johnson/NPR)

Tanisha Cortez waits on a table at a restaurant in Ames, Iowa. When the previous restaurant she worked for closed, Cortez applied to others and had job offers right away. 
Ames, Iowa, has an unemployment rate of 1.5%, making it the tightest job market in the country. That's great for workers — but a challenge for those looking for them. (Image: @olivia__sun | Olivia Sun for NPR)

Restraint and seclusion are controversial practices in public schools. They are most often used on students with disabilities, and parents say they take an emotional toll.(Image: @leonardo.santamaria | Leonardo Santamaria for NPR)

Physicians often harbor unconscious bias against kids and teens with obesity. It affects how they talk with their patients and can make kids' health worse. Some doctors are trying a new approach. (Image: @andreadaquino_pictures | Andrea D'Aquino for NPR)

Kamaran Najm is an Iraqi photojournalist who had a vision: to create the first photo agency in Iraq that focused on hiring local photographers. Najm wanted to take images that represented the beauty and reality of Iraq that the war usually overpowered. Five years after creating the Metrography Photo Agency, Najm went missing. Officials informed his friends and family that he was dead. But he wasn’t. He’d been captured by ISIS. NPR’s Rough Translation follows a tense rescue operation in real-time – from phone calls with ISIS, to sorting through false leads, to tribal allegiances – as they figure out who they can trust. And how to save their friend. Follow the link in our bio to hear Kamaran Najm’s story. (Image: @sebmeyerphoto | Sebastian Meyer)

Fatima – and other women in conflict zones – are often perceived as victims. They may be in many cases, but they also hold multiple and sometimes conflicting identities: as fighters, breadwinners and leaders. Photographer Robin Hammond | @hammond_robin sought to capture the many roles they play in his series of portraits, "Making the Invisible Visible," which had its first public showing this past week at the Women Deliver 2019 Global Conference in Vancouver, Canada. 
1. Fatima Dahiru, now 17, lives with her sister and mother in an internally displaced persons camp in Maiduguri, Nigeria. Her village was attacked two years ago.
2. Noraisa Macud, 52, fled the fighting between Philippine military forces and Islamic militants in Marawi, a predominantly Muslim city, in 2017. Hundreds of thousands of residents were displaced. Macud escaped with five of her six children but hasn't seen her 29-year-old son since. She now lives in an evacuation center.
3. This Iraqi woman suffered burns to her face and arms when her house in Mosul was hit by mortar fire.
4. Hozan Badeea Sindi, now 27, stands in front of the blanket she slept under during her many months as an intern at a hospital in the Kurdish region of Iraq.
5. This Filipina teenager is now living in an evacuation center after her family fled fighting between the military and militants in the southern city of Marawi in 2017.

Black men have the lowest life expectancy of any major demographic group. Doctor and researcher Owen Garrick and his colleagues wondered what it would take to get black men to go to the doctor for preventative care. They had a hunch that race might be a factor. So they ran a field study to try to answer one simple question: Will black men take more preventative care services if they are randomly assigned to a black doctor? The study found that black men assigned to a black doctor did accept more preventative services. And not by a little — by a lot. Follow the link in our bio for the full episode of Hidden Brain. (Image: @hisiheyah | Angela Hsieh/NPR)

To make sure each partner is on the same page, kinksters have to talk about sex in a way that vanilla people — those who don't participate in kinky activities — often don't. Julie, a kinkster and sociologist in the Washington, D.C., area, believes that the communication kinksters have with one another distinguishes them from "vanillas." Click on the link in bio to read about other lessons we can learn from the kink community. (Image: @nicolexu_ | Nicole Xu for NPR)

A hired goat eats vegetation on a private landowner's property in Auburn, Calif. Legacy Ranching hires out a mix of goats and sheep to munch away fuel on fire-prone hillsides and parks. 
Across the West, hundreds of communities are vulnerable to wildfires. But Post-Paradise, communities are "hardening" their towns against wildfire like never before. Follow the link in our bio for the full story. (Image: @mererizzo | Meredith Rizzo/NPR)

This week, the world is marking 75 years since the D-Day invasion. As the anniversary approached, photographer Luke Sharrett started planning a pilgrimage to the hallowed shores and hedgerows of Normandy. He felt he needed to pay his respects to the brave men who cracked Adolf Hitler's Atlantic Wall of defenses. 
This desire propelled Sharrett into the ranks of the World War II Airborne Demonstration Team. The group performs parachute jumps dressed in authentic WWII equipment at air shows and veterans' events around the United States and Europe. This week he traveled to France with 79 of his fellow team members. Follow the link in our bio for the full story. (Images: @howdyluke | Luke Sharrett for NPR) #nprpictureshow

In 2018, Jack Sawyer told police he wanted to set a new record: highest death count for a school shooter. He was arrested, but the courts had to decide whether Sawyer's plan was even a crime. Follow the link in our bio for the full story. (Image: @itschrisnickels | Chris Nickels for NPR)

Three years ago this week, NPR journalists David Gilkey and Zabihullah Tamanna were killed while on assignment in Afghanistan. They were traveling with the Afghan National Army when their convoy was ambushed. John Poole, NPR's senior visuals editor, remembers his friend and colleague:

David was an artist, and he was also a soldier. Or maybe it was the other way around. Either way, he produced some of the most remarkable images of war and crisis that have ever been made. He could paint with his camera like an old master, even in the middle of hot fire. It is a miracle that he could do what he did.

Amid the death and destruction that he witnessed over and over and over again, he found the fragile beauty in all of it.

For seeing the truth and the beauty in the things that most people turn away from, he played the role of witness for us all. In his pictures, we see through his eyes and his soul, and we hope — and maybe believe — that the beauty and compassion will win.

Follow the link in our bio for the full story and photo gallery. (Images by David Gilkey / NPR)

This month, never before seen images from Tiananman Square protests are being shared with the public for the first time. The photos evoke a path not taken — an alternate reality in which the spontaneous gatherings and freewheeling, open-air political debates captured in them that spring were still possible today. The photos were taken by one of the student protestors, Jian Liu, who now lives in California. Follow the link in our bio for the full story. (Images: Jian Liu/Humanitarian China) #nprpictureshow

In the 1970s, Rich Isaacson was presented with what seemed like a crazy idea: using lasers to detect gravitational waves. It became the biggest project the National Science Foundation had ever funded. Follow the link in our bio for the full story. (Image: @rjckseen | Ryan Kellman/NPR)

So many food labels proclaim their eco-virtues these days — Organic. Pasture-raised. Cage-free. Non-GMO. What do they actually mean? Follow the link in our bio to hear the full Life Kit episode. (Image: @lindseybalbierz | Lindsey Balbierz for NPR)

Susan and Keith Koppelman have been living on a rural property since being evicted from their trailer home after Hurricane Michael. They're among tens of thousands of Floridians who've been forced out of their homes since Michael. Some are still homeless. And Congress has yet to pass a disaster relief funding bill — something that typically happens weeks after a major storm. 
Nearly eight months later, this year's Atlantic hurricane season has officially begun. Follow the link in our bio for the full story. (Image: @misterwidmer | William Widmer for NPR)

More than 200 migrants die attempting to cross the Southwest border each year. Slowly, scientists at a laboratory at Texas State University are seeking to identify their remains. Follow the link in our bio for the full story. (Image: @katiehayesluke | Katie Hayes Luke for NPR)

There are more barrels of bourbon in Kentucky today than at any point since the 1970s. Bourbon was born in Kentucky, and today the industry is in the middle of a renaissance, even as trade disputes and tariffs threaten its growth. Follow the link in our bio for the full story. (Photos: @howdyluke | Luke Sharrett for Here & Now)

The Smith family is part of an influx of African Americans to Mecklenburg County, North Carolina, where the African American population has ballooned by 64% since 2000. Some people come from neighboring counties in North and South Carolina, but thousands are from Ohio, New York, Pennsylvania, New Jersey and Illinois. As manufacturing has dried up in the Rust Belt, services, tech and finance industries have grown in Southern cities, and some African Americans have started heading back South. Follow the link in our bio for the full story. (Image: @swikarpatel | Swikar Patel for NPR)

American men face higher rates of suicide than women and higher rates of incarceration. In the age of #MeToo, some men are turning to each other to build healthy esteem that builds up others too. Follow the link in our bio for the full story. (Image: @leonardo.santamaria | Leonardo Santamaria for NPR)

China is a world superpower today. But just over a century ago, the country was in complete turmoil — foreign powers had carved up the country, the ruling dynasty was losing control, and millions of citizens were struggling to survive. However, that political chaos inspired a nationalist movement that reshaped China as we know it, and it was led by one man - Sun Yat-sen. (Image: @hisiheyah | Angela Hsieh/NPR)

Alondra Martinez (right) recently graduated from Montclair State University. She's part of the record number of Hispanics going to college: Enrollment nearly tripled between 1999 and 2016. When her dad came to the U.S. from Mexico in the '90s, his first job only paid him $120. Since then, things have improved dramatically for their family. In the early 2000s, Alondra's parents were able to buy their house in New Jersey. "Being a first-generation college student means breaking every barrier, silencing every negative voice and pushing myself to be the woman I know I am meant to be," Alondra said. Then, turning to her parents, she said, "Mamá, papá, lo logramos" –– Mom, dad, we made it. (Image: @mosadek | Mohamed Sadek for NPR)

Around 15% of girls begin menstruation by age 7. The challenges of puberty can rock anybody, but being the first of your friends to go through it can be especially stressful. Good parenting helps. Follow the link in our bio for the full story. (Image: @pmvickers | Paige Vickers for NPR)

At 37 years old and having held no higher office than mayor, Pete Buttigieg has gone from an unknown presidential candidate with a difficult-to-pronounce name to holding well-attended rallies and generating buzz with televised town halls over the course of a couple months. 
One thing that has helped him earn attention in the crowded 23-person Democratic field is how he talks about his faith and how he talks about his marriage to husband, Chasten. (Image: @olivia__sun | Olivia Sun for NPR)

Children have a natural affinity for math, but sometimes we as the adults in their lives bring our own anxiety to the subject. NPR’s LA Johnson @neoncatdc walks us through simple ways to nurture our kids’ love of math in a short comic. Swipe through to read.

Dani Izzie with her service dog, Zandra. She works as a social media manager for Spinergy, a company that makes high-performance wheels for wheelchairs. The company welcomed Zandra, who is able to retrieve things when Izzie drops them. ⠀⠀
⠀⠀
The nation's disability rolls swelled during the Great Recession. But more disabled people are now finding work, and employers are more willing to make allowances, thanks to the tight job market. Follow the link in our bio for the full story. (Image: @gregkahn | Greg Kahn for NPR)

Photographer Soumya Sankar Bose remembers how Jatra, a style of folk theater, was popular during his childhood in West Bengal. But 10 years after moving out, Bose returned home to find that Jatra was disappearing. The genre's brightest stars, once major celebrities, were fading from view. Even his own uncle, a famous Jatra performer, had taken a job at a train station to make ends meet. Moved by his uncle's experience, Bose began a multiyear journey to document an art tradition that is slowly vanishing. (Image: @soumyasankarbose | Soumya Sankar Bose) #nprpictureshow

Courtney Hering has worked in the Kohler distribution center, moving finished faucets and unfinished brass, since 2012. It was only after she'd been working there for a couple of years that Hering realized something startling: Many of her colleagues doing exactly the same work were paid nearly twice as much as she was. "It made me realize, 'Oh man, this is a huge gap,' " Hering says.⠀⠀
⠀⠀
That gap was a hangover from the Great Recession, when workers lost negotiating power and companies found a way to reduce wages. Now a tight labor market is giving workers the leverage they need to demand a larger slice of the nation's economic pie. Follow the link in our bio for the full story. (Image: @sarastathas | Sara Stathas for NPR)
Pain is more than an unpleasant sensation. When pain signals reach the brain, they interact with areas involved in thinking, memory and emotion. (Image: @itschrisnickels | Chris Nickels for NPR)

Carly Rae Jepsen has evolved into one of pop's most endearing and indelible voices; her relatable lyrics hit home but her dance-pop arrangements soar above the everyday. Jepsen's latest album, Dedicated, finds the 33-year-old navigating those strange, reaffirming moments in between love and loss. Across 13 tracks, Jepsen takes fans through every phase of a relationship. (Image: @mererizzo & @rjckseen | Meredith Rizzo & Ryan Kellman/NPR)

Re-entry programs work like a bridge between the world of corrections and the world of social services. Follow the link in our bio to find out what one of those programs is doing to help folks stay out for good. (Image: @ankegladnick | Anke Gladnick for NPR)

On May 18, 2018, police say a student killed 10 people and wounded 13 others in a shooting at Santa Fe High School. Sarah Salazar is one of those who were wounded. 
One year and seven surgeries later, Sarah still has shotgun pellets embedded in her body. "Some days I'll just wake up and be like, 'Today is not going to be a good day,'" she says. 
Follow the link in our bio for the story of one teen's struggle to rebuild her life after it was nearly taken from her. (Image: @_allisonhess | Allison Hess for NPR)

Two-humped Bactrian camels were domesticated thousands of years ago to carry goods and people across Asia. Every year, herders come to one Gobi Desert town to celebrate these gentle giants.  1. A camel stands tethered at the edge of the festival grounds, his ankles wrapped for polo.

2. Gobi herder Enkhbaatar Dashnyam, 59.

3. Gobi herder Dulamsuren Yunden, 47, dresses for the festival's Beautiful Couple Contest.

4. Camels stand with their herders.

5. Byambasaikhan Sanjid, 45, is a local camel trainer. (Images: @claireeclaire | Claire Harbage/NPR )

Smarts matter. But other factors may play an even bigger role in whether someone succeeds. New research suggests that early investments in children's education can have benefits that last for more than one generation. Follow the link in our bio to hear the full story. (Image: @hisiheyah | Angela Hsieh/NPR)

Elizabeth Warren has built her brand on prolific policy proposals. But she is also using folksy charm to try to win support at campaign stops in towns big and small. Warren recently made campaign stops in West Virginia and Ohio.

1. Elizabeth Warren speaks at a campaign stop at the Kermit, W.Va., fire department. 
2. Kermit has a population of about 400 and is believed to have been visited by only one other presidential candidate, John F. Kennedy. 
3. The crowd at Warren's campaign stop at an elementary school in Columbus, Ohio. Here, as at her previous stop in West Virginia, Warren spoke extensively about the opioid crisis and how it has affected each of the places she visited.

4. Campaign buttons are displayed before Warren’s Cincinnati town hall.

5. Warren hugs a supporter at the end of her event in Cincinnati. (Images: @andyspear and @johndavid_richardson | Andrew Spear and John-David Richardson for NPR)

The municipal cemetery in Lares, Puerto Rico, has been closed since Hurricane Maria hit. Residents flocked to visit when a portion of the cemetery was opened for Mother's Day on Sunday, but many were unable to reach their loved ones' graves.

In the second photo, Eligia González, 84, (left) and her daughter, Carmen Román, 54, brought flowers to the Lares Municipal Cemetery. Román felt she had been deceived, after she realized her grandmother's grave was inaccessible. (Images: @erikaprodriguez | Erika P. Rodríguez for NPR)

WHITE LIES is a new NPR true crime podcast about the unsolved murder of James Reeb, a white Unitarian minister and civil rights activist. In 1965, Reeb traveled from his home in Boston to Selma, Ala., to march with Martin Luther King Jr. following the Bloody Sunday protests at the Edmund Pettus Bridge. He was attacked along with two other white ministers while walking from Walker’s Café, a black-owned restaurant in downtown Selma. He died two days later. 
NPR returned to Selma more than 50 years later to uncover the truth about what really happened to Reeb and to talk with the people whose lives have been forever changed by his murder. Photos by @misterwidmer. 1. Joanne Bland is the co-founder of the National Voting Rights Museum in Selma. 2. Edmund Pettus Bridge. 3. Walker’s Café. 4. A plaque dedicated in memory of James Reeb stands at the site of the attack on Reeb.

From the archives: Maria de los Angeles Tun Burgos with daughters Angela, 12, and Gelmy, 9, in their family home in a Maya village in Yucatán, Mexico. There's no other way to put it: Burgos is a supermom.⠀⠀
⠀⠀
She's raising five children, does housework and chores — we're talking about fresh tortillas every day made from stone-ground corn — and she helps with the family's business in their small village about 2 1/2 hours west of Cancún on the Yucatán Peninsula. ⠀⠀
⠀⠀
Burgos is constantly on parental duty but in general, she shows no sense of chronic worry or stress. "I know that raising kids is slow," she says. "Little by little they will learn." (Image: @adrianazehbrauskas | Adriana Zehbrauskas for NPR)

Naju Dorma, 73, and Lacuo Dorma, 66, belong to the Mosuo society in China, where grandmothers head up households. Many studies show that women are less willing to take risks than men are. But new research, on girls from the Mosuo community in China run by women, offers insights into what leads to more risk taking.(Image: @karolinklueppel | Karolin Klüppel)

Our biology makes it hard to lose weight. In this episode, we won't tell you how to lose weight — or whether you even need to. We will give you five realities about biology, and they might even help you be kinder to your body. (Image: @shannondrewthis | Shannon Wright for NPR)

Three years ago, the National Aquarium in Baltimore decided it would find a sanctuary in the wild for its prized pod of dolphins. But then climate change complicated the plan entirely. (Images: @claireeclaire | Claire Harbage/NPR)

Akiya Parks, who graduated on Saturday from the University of Florida, is one of the nearly 4 million students students raising children while working towards a degree. "It motivated me more to finish," Parks says, reflecting on college life with her 3-year-old son Caleb. "It wasn't like, 'oh man he's gonna slow me down.' I don't want him to feel like he held me back from anything, because he didn't." (Credit: @elissanad | Elissa Nadworny/NPR)

Reaching out in kindness, mindful breathing and taking time daily to note positive moments and personal strengths are all part of a program that reduces anxiety and depression for caregivers. But it takes practice to cultivate joy. (Image: @cornelia_illo | Cornelia Li for NPR)

A 16-year-old girl was the first in her family to make it to 10th grade. When she saw her final exam grades, she was upset and then she killed herself. Her death is a tragic reminder of the pressures teenage girls face in India. (Image: @lilypadula | Lily Padula for NPR)

Tennessee Reconnect has helped thousands of adults afford a college education, but for many older students, the financial support may not be enough to get them to the finish line. (Image: @yifanwuart | Yifan Wu for NPR)

Victoria Libsack is a teacher at Linus Pauling Middle School in Corvallis, Ore. She taught for three years in a low-income Phoenix school. But after her TEACH Grants were converted into more than $20,000 in loans, she took a job at a school that doesn't meet TEACH requirements.⁣⠀
⁣⠀
Nearly 2,300 teachers have just had a mountain of student loan debt lifted off their backs, according to previously unreleased figures from the U.S. Department of Education. The move follows reporting by NPR that exposed a nightmare for public school teachers across the country.⁣⠀
⁣⠀
In exchange for agreeing to work in low-income schools, aspiring teachers could get federal Teacher Education Assistance for College and Higher Education (TEACH) Grants from the department to help pay their way through college. But those grants were often unfairly turned into loans that teachers had to pay back.⁣⠀
⁣⠀
In December, the Education Department proposed a fix. Now, that fix has been expanded, and thousands more teachers are likely to get help. (Image: @bethnakamura | Beth Nakamura for NPR)

In 2011 John Foley had an idea but:⁣⠀
⁣⠀
- Didn’t have the money to launch⁣⠀
- Had no idea how to build an online platform⁣⠀
- Knew nothing about the fitness industry⁣⠀
- Was in his late 40s with kids and a mortgage⁣⠀
⁣⠀
And yet today Peloton is valued at over $4B. Foley spoke to Guy Raz on a recent How I Built This podcast episode. (Image: @connorheckert | Connor Heckert for NPR)

Now that they're married, Laura and Adam Hardin clearly have figured it out: their two toddlers were pattering around upstairs in their modest home in a Washington, D.C., suburb when NPR visited recently. And Laura's belly was bulging with their third baby — a daughter born last week.⁣⠀
⁣⠀
But Adam remembers some anxious moments on their honeymoon almost five years ago — the first time either of them had sex.⁣⠀
⁣⠀
Waiting until marriage to have sex is relatively rare in the United States. It's tough to measure how many people are currently waiting, but according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, close to 90% of people who have ever been married say they've had premarital sex. (Image: @clarefieseler | Clare Fieseler for NPR)

Photojournalist Tommy Trenchard was "overwhelmed" by what he saw while documenting the second killer cyclone to strike Mozambique in the past six weeks. More than 20 inches of rain fell over a couple of days — with another 20 inches forecast this week. (Images: @tommy.trenchard | Tommy Trenchard for NPR)

Bells, rattles and thumb pianos are among the iron instruments used to summon ancestors. An exhibit at the Smithsonian's National Museum of African Art highlights the remarkable skills and creativity of iron workers from over 100 ethnic groups across the continent. (Image: @olivia__sun | Olivia Sun for NPR)

April is National Poetry Month, so on this episode, NPR’s Code Switch podcast is passing the mic to a handful of talented poets — the people who narrate our lives and help us better understand our own experiences. Poets are shown with an excerpt of their work.

Hieu Minh Nguyen – “Uptown, Minneapolis, Minnesota”
Ashley M. Jones – "Slurret”
Féi Hernandez – “Serpent Diosa”
Jericho Brown – “Stand”
Fatimah Asghar – “Kul”
Kaveh Akbar – “Reza’s Restaurant, Chicago, 1997"
Ada Limon – “The Contract Says: We’d Like The Conversation To Be Bilingual" (Images: @neoncatdc | LA Johnson/NPR)

Tourists are flocking to California to see the origins of their favorite tech companies. Now there might be a monument about Silicon Valley's glory. (Images: @jamestensuan | James Tensuan for NPR) #nprpictureshow

In an NPR/Ipsos poll, 65% of teachers said they don't talk about climate change because it's not related to the subjects they teach. Here are some tips that you can use in any classroom:⁣⠀
⁣⠀
- Do a service project⁣⠀
- Assign a novel⁣⠀
- Start or work in a school garden⁣⠀
- Talk about your personal experience⁣⠀
⁣⠀
(Image: @hisiheyah | Angela Hsieh/NPR)

On a bright Sunday afternoon in early March, the Tamir River in the steppes of Mongolia becomes a bowling alley. Two dozen Mongolian herdsmen have gathered to play ‘musun shagai,’ known as ""ice shooting."" Right now, the ice on the river is perfect. Clear and smooth. The players are cheerful and focused.

Their goal? To send a small copper puck called a zakh down a 93-yard stretch of ice and knock over several cow ankle bones — painted red, none bigger than a golf ball — at the other end. Extra points for hitting the biggest target, made of cow skin.

This competition, originally scheduled for mid-March, was bumped up by two weeks. "The river was already melting," Gurvantamir Jamts said. (Images: @claireeclaire | Claire Harbage/NPR)

Artificial intelligence, gene modification, and self-driving cars are causing fear and uncertainty about how technology is changing our lives. But humans have struggled to accept innovations throughout history. In this episode, we explore three innovations that transformed the world and show how people have adapted — and ask whether we can do the same today. (Image: @hisiheyah | Angela Hsieh/NPR)⁣⠀

Venezuelan photographer Fabiola Ferrero traveled to Colombia with two instant cameras. Her goal: to portray a country in limbo between war and peace. “I wanted to pay attention to coca farmers because the increase of coca crops was seen as the biggest threat to peace,” Ferrero says.

She stayed with a coca-growing family for a week. Ferrero established a connection with the head of the family, a raspachín or coca farmer, and with his family. She asked them to visually convey — with paper and markers — what life is like and their idea of peace. (Images: @fabiolaferrero |Fabiola Ferrero) #nprpictureshow

David Lockwood (in white) and Larry Kahn (in blue), "the Ali-Frazier" of Tiddlywinks, are vying to win the World Pairs title. To the professional winkers, the game is far more than shooting discs, or "winks," into a cup. (Images and video: @claireeclaire| Claire Harbage/NPR)

Plants and wildlife have grown unrestrained for decades in the demilitarized zone (DMZ) between North and South Korea. The area is fortified with tall, barbed-wire fences, riddled with land mines and heavily guarded by the respective countries' militaries, keeping all human disturbances to a minimum. But with increasing goodwill between the two countries, environmentalists fear that the protected nature of the area is changing and may lead to detrimental effects on the wildlife. (Images: @claireeclaire | Claire Harbage/NPR)
As the work of many experimental and pop musicians shows, sounds made by a body that don't cohere into recognizable language can still have emotional clarity. (Image: @hisiheyah |  Angela Hsieh/NPR)

Jessica Calise checks on her son Joseph as he gets ready for bed. Joseph used to be afraid to sleep alone, but he has learned to be OK with it since his mother learned new parenting approaches. For some kids with anxiety disorders, a new study suggests the best treatment might be teaching their parents new skills. (Image: @chriscappyphoto | Christopher Capozziello for NPR)

The Sunni-Shia divide is a conflict that most people have heard about - two sects with Sunni Islam being in the majority and Shia Islam the minority. Exactly how did this conflict originate and when?
