"Sight isn't the only pathway to understand art," says Carol Wilson of the Smithsonian American Art Museum in Washington, D.C. There, specially trained docents lead tours using sound, description — and even touch — for blind and visually impaired visitors. Follow the link in the bio for the full story. (Credit: @raqzal | Raquel Zaldivar/NPR)

Yoga has been promoted as the cure for many ills, from diabetes to insomnia. Scientific proof is mixed. But this skeptic says if yoga makes climbing the stairs hurt less, that's good enough. Follow the link in our bio for the full story. (Credit: @jennliv | Jenn Liv for NPR)

On-site manager Nancy Stock places new numbers on a mailbox at Park Plaza Cooperative outside Minneapolis. A neighborhood in Minnesota is proving that there's a potential solution to run-down mobile home parks: The residents banded together democratically and took over their community. Follow the link in our bio for more photos and the full story. (Credit: @bridgetkbennett | Bridget Bennett for NPR)

Jasper Barnett, a junior at Thomas Jefferson High School for Science and Technology in Alexandria, Va., looks up in the school's planetarium. Once, there were more than 300 planetariums in schools around the country. Many are still around, but they're getting old. Schools have a choice: Keep the stars shining, or turn the lights out. Follow the link in our bio for the full story. (Credit: @elissanad | Elissa Nadworny/NPR) 💫

An after-school program called HOLA — which stands for "Heart of Los Angeles" — serves the city's Rampart District, where nearly all its residents live in poverty. Over nearly 30 years, the program has helped hundreds go to college. A handful of students from the scientific arts program at HOLA have pursued successful technical careers. But a lot of the students shy away from the tech industry, despite technical talents: They don't want jobs with any economic risk — something quite common for work at a startup or in computer science in general. ⠀
⠀
⠀
As you go through the tech talent "pipeline" to find where it leaks, HOLA illustrates a major one. Somewhere between middle school and high-school graduation, girls' interest in tech peaks and wanes. So where do girls and women drop out from the tech talent pipeline? Follow the link in our bio for the full story. (Credit: @chelseabeck.psd | Chelsea Beck/NPR) #technology #illustration #womenintech

At the Lewisburg federal penitentiary in central Pennsylvania, one of the toughest prisons in America, doubling up inmates in cells designed for solitary confinement can lead to violence, and for some who refuse a cellmate, handcuffs and chains. According to inmates' lawyers, Lewisburg staffers and more than 40 current and former inmates — who made similar claims in lawsuits, court testimonies, government audits or letters and interviews with The Marshall Project and NPR — restraints are used as punishment at Lewisburg, often for prisoners who refuse their cell assignments.
⠀
According to federal incident report records obtained by The Marshall Project and NPR, officers responded to 228 in-cell fights and assaults with restraints or pepper spray in 2014 and 2015. At least 19 inmates were treated for injuries such as a collapsed lung, a broken rib, multiple stab wounds and head injuries. The Special Management Unit (or SMU) at Lewisburg was created in 2009 for "dangerously violent, confrontational, defiant, antagonistic inmates,” according to the Bureau of Prisons. Since the SMU opened, there have been more than 800 recorded inmate-on-inmate assaults — a rate six times higher than all federal prisons. And in that time, at least four inmates have been killed by their cellmates.
⠀
Follow the link in our bio for the full investigation. (Credit: Angie Wang for NPR)

[2/2] Dawn Tachell's yard in Syringa Mobile Home Park looks out to mountains near Moscow, Idaho. She bought the house 13 years ago, fulfilling her dream to own a home. The federal government estimates there are more than 8 million "manufactured houses" (which is what the government has called mobile homes built since 1976). Housing specialists say they play an important role in "boosting affordable home ownership opportunities," according to a Ford Foundation report. But the decades-old saga of Syringa Mobile Home Park and other evidence suggest that the legal and financial ways in which manufactured housing communities are set up often turn the residents into victims. Follow the link in our bio for more photos and to read part one of our two-part report on conditions at mobile home parks in the U.S. (Credit: @jedconklin | Jed Conklin for NPR) #housing #community #investigation #idaho

[1/2] The community center at the Syringa Mobile Home Park near Moscow, Idaho, has been closed and the pool once used by its residents has shut down and is now filled with scum. Conditions in the neighborhood have become so bad that some people have abandoned their houses and moved out. Mobile home park residents wanting an affordable way to own a home say they're at the community's owner's mercy when it comes to their daily quality of life. 
Follow the link in our bio for more photos and to read part one of our two-part report on conditions at mobile home parks in the U.S. (Credit: @jedconklin | Jed Conklin for NPR) #housing #community #investigation #idaho
Some campuses are testing new tools that give professors access to real-time data on student engagement and performance. Follow the link in our bio for the full story. (Credit: Martin Gee for NPR)

Lorenzo Palma (center) reviews family documents with his brother and mother in their home in El Paso, Texas. Palma served time for a parole violation and, just as he was being released, was sent before an immigration court to prove his U.S. citizenship. It's illegal for immigration officials to detain U.S. citizens. But an NPR analysis of public records found that in an eight-year period, some 1,500 people who had been held turned out to be Americans. Follow the link in our bio for the full story and more photos. (Credit: Bree Lamb for NPR)

Pastry chef Aggie Chin talks with NPR's Ailsa Chang about sweet treats to prepare for your holiday party. This week, it's pear upside down spice cake. Follow the link in our bio to the recipe and hear full conversation. (Credit: @claireeclaire | Claire Harbage/NPR) 🍐

Six months ago a shooter opened fire in the Pulse nightclub in Orlando, killing 49 people and wounding 53 more. “The 12th of June was the darkest day in our history, but I couldn't be more proud of our community at this point because of the way we have rallied and responded at this point — not being defined by the act of the gunman but being defined by how we have responded," Orlando Mayor Buddy Dyer said. Our Story has more images and quotes from people touched by the tragedy. (Credit: @cassialexandra | Cassi Alexandra)

Six months ago a shooter opened fire in the Pulse nightclub in Orlando, killing 49 people and wounding 53 more. Aryam Guerrero, Mayra Guerrero, Juan Ramon and Celia Ruiz lost their youngest son and brother, Juan Guerrero, that night. "I think [acceptance] comes from the family," Celia says. "We can talk about what the schools are doing and what the church is doing, but it comes from the family. It's the way that you raise your kids. If you raise your kids to think that it's wrong to be gay, then your child is going to have a tough teenager life trying to share that with you." Our Story has more images and quotes from people touched by the tragedy. (Credit: @cassialexandra | Cassi Alexandra)

President Obama sits down with NPR’s @steve_inskeep for a final interview before leaving office. They discuss a variety of topics including Donald Trump, Russian cyberattacks and his plans for the future. Follow the link in our bio to watch the the first clip from the interview. (Credit: Ariel Zambelich/NPR)

A group of students at the Calicut Medical College in Kerala, India wanted to get people to speak more openly about periods. So they launched a poetry contest. Follow the link in our bio for the full story. (Credit: @hannabarczyk | Hanna Barczyk for NPR)

Alsarah was born in Sudan to politically active parents. When she was still a child a coup there forced the family to flee to Yemen. Then, after civil war broke out in Yemen, they had to flee again, this time to Amherst, Massachusetts — all by the time Alsarah was 12. But please, says the singer-songwriter, don't pigeonhole her as some sort of "refugee artist." Follow the link in our bio for the full story and to see her #TinyDesk Concert performance. (Credit: @rjckseen | Ryan Kellman/NPR)

A new study on high-quality early learning programs shows a robust long-term return on investment. The most potent ingredients? Parental engagement and empathy. (Credit: @thelajohnson | LA Johnson/NPR) #education

Alexander Howland, 21, is one of the protesters living in a temporary camp at the Standing Rock Sioux Reservation in North Dakota. He traveled to the protest site from Dulce, N.M., on the Jicarilla Apache Reservation. He arrived in mid-August, intending to stay for a week, but he has ended up staying into the winter. "I'm going to stay as long as it takes to ensure the safety of our future generations, to make sure that they have water for their children, for my children, for my future generations to come, for everyone's future generations to come," Howland said. Check out our Story for more images and quotes from protesters. (Credit: @cassi_alexandra | Cassi Alexandra for NPR)

Daphne Singingtree, 65, is one of the protesters living in a temporary camp at the Standing Rock Sioux Reservation in North Dakota. She is a traditional practitioner and a medicine maker from Eugene, Ore., though her father's side of her family is from Standing Rock. Singingtree has been at Standing Rock for weeks at a time, driving from Oregon to North Dakota with a truck of supplies and belongings. "It's more than this pipeline, on this land, at this time. I see this movement continuing on," Singingtree said. Check out our Story for more images and quotes from protesters. (Credit: @cassi_alexandra | Cassi Alexandra for NPR)

The dementia wing of a nursing home is foreign territory to most people. Photographer Maja Daniels spent three years documenting the lives of people with Alzheimer's and dementia in a French hospital. Through this project, Daniels became the inaugural winner of the Bob and Diane Fund, a grant for visual storytelling about Alzheimer's disease and dementia. Follow the link in our bio for more photos and an interview with the photographer. (Credit: @majadaniels | Maja Daniels)

Sure, brown rice is better for you than refined white rice. But if you cringe when you see it on sushi, there's good reason behind that, and it's rooted in flavor science and biochemistry. Follow the link in our bio for the full story. (Credit: Erin Bushnell for NPR)

The Army Corps of Engineers has decided to deny the easement for the construction of the Dakota Access Pipeline. The decision essentially halts the construction of the oil pipeline about half a mile south of the Standing Rock Sioux Reservation. The decision also comes as demonstrators across the country flocked to North Dakota in protest. Follow the link in our bio for the full story. (Credit: @cttobin | Celia Talbot Tobin for NPR)

Volunteers started working the day after Thanksgiving to give the White House its annual holiday charm. This year's White House Gingerbread House is made with 150 pounds of gingerbread, 100 pounds of bread dough, 20 pounds of gum paste, 20 pounds of icing and 20 pounds of sculpted sugar pieces. Kolaches have been a Lone Star staple for a long time, and some have even taken on a sausage-and-jalapeño twist. Now the Czech pastry's popularity is expanding outside of Texas, with both big and small companies getting onboard. Follow the link in our bio for the full story. Kids are showing reading gains in dual-language classrooms. There may be underlying brain advantages at work. Follow the link in our bio for the full story. (Credit: @chelseabeck.psd | Chelsea Beck/NPR)

There's a plethora of projects to gather data about the brain, various kinds of cancer and every type of cell in the body. But researchers are struggling to keep up with the information explosion. Follow the link in our bio for the full story. (Credit: Katherine Streeter for NPR)

Dyslexia is the most common learning disability, yet it's still hard to answer the question: What is it? A NPR reporter who has dyslexia talks with other people — young and old — in search of answers. Follow the link in our bio for the full story. (Credit: @thelajohnson | LA Johnson/NPR)

Chef Mike Isabella, a renowned restaurateur, has devised some delectable spinoffs of traditional Thanksgiving accompaniments, while staying true to classic roots. Lung cancer affects mostly older people, but they're often not offered surgery as a treatment. A study finds that most older people can tolerate surgery, and that it extends lives. When Morton Pollner (center) was diagnosed with lung cancer at age 76, he thought it was a death sentence. It's been seven years since he had surgery for lung cancer. Pollner is now 82 and takes Tai Chi classes three times a week at the local synagogue. Follow the link in our bio for the full story. (Credit: Michael Rubenstein for NPR)⠀

Anthony David Martinez raises his hand in class at the Escuela 20 Noviembre school in Tijuana, Mexico. Muslim commentator Beenish Ahmed says the election results "make official a nostalgia for a whiter America." Follow the link in our bio for the full essay. (Credit: @chelseabeck.psd | Chelsea Beck/NPR)

Ad campaigns from the first and second World Wars sold Americans on this surprising pairing of salt and grapefruit. Despite a rocky history of breakups, the chemistry between these two flavors cannot be denied. Follow the link in our bio for the full story. (Credit: Joy Ho and Meredith Rizzo/NPR)

Georgia State University says it has saved students $12 million in tuition because they're graduating faster, thanks to its new high-tech advising system. Follow the link in our bio for the full story. (Credit: @thelajohnson | LA Johnson/NPR) #education

Rebecca Canalija, 57, waits for Hillary Clinton to speak at the Javits Center in New York City on Tuesday night. It has been nearly two decades since California imposed significant restrictions on bilingual education and mandated English-only instruction for the state's 1.4 million English-language learners (ELLs). But on this year's ballot, Proposition 58 will give voters a chance to lift those restrictions and make it easier for parents to choose. Alice Callaghan (left), of Las Familias Del Pueblos in Los Angeles, says bilingual education slows down English language acquisition; Hilda Maldonado (right), executive director of the Multilingual and Multicultural Education Department of the Los Angeles Unified School District, supports bilingual education. A study offering the parents of newborns a scan of thousands of the baby's genes raises a big question: Do you want this kind of information on disease risk in your child's permanent record? Follow the link in our bio for the full story. (Credit: @scottbakal | Scott Bakal for NPR)

Elaborately decorated skulls are crafted from pure sugar and given to friends as gifts. The colorful designs represent the vitality of life and individual personality. The Mexican tradition, Día de los Muertos, celebrates the dead and welcomes their return to the land of the living once a year. Enticing them to make the trip is where the food, drink and musical offerings come in. Follow the link in our bio for more photos. (Credit: Karen Castillo Farfán/NPR)

A subway ride hammers home the reality that many Muslims face: While they fear being hurt by terrorists and vigilantes, others see them as a threat. Follow the link in our bio for the full essay. (Credit: Ashely Mackenzie for NPR)

Kids may be little. But the cost of paying for someone to take care of them is really big. Stressed-out parents are pinching pennies, driving for Uber and putting off saving and having more kids. Follow the link in our bio for the full story. (Credit: @chelseabeck.psd | Chelsea Beck/NPR)

Researchers are exploring changes in prenatal nutrition to lower risks for future mental disorders. The work is preliminary, but there is ample precedent for maternal diet affecting children's health. Follow the link in our bio for the full story. (Credit: Katherine Streeter for NPR)

Migrants arrive to register for relocation at a temporary facility outside "The Jungle" refugee camp near the port of Calais, France. U.S. schools are scrambling to teach millions of students who don't speak English. That means more program options and better services. Here's a look at the three most common approaches. Follow the link in our bio for the full story. (Credit: Jenn Liv for NPR)

What makes for quality child care? It depends whom you ask. Parents look for a place where their child will be loved and happy, but often have to make decisions based on cost and location. Researchers are looking for a rich developmental experience. Follow the link in our bio for the full story. (Credit Michelle Kondrich for NPR)

Helmut Bode oversees the factory at the General Pencil Company in Jersey City, N.J. He’s been in the pencil industry for nearly 40 years and the company has been making pencils since 1889. Reproductions of the types of clothing slaves wore in the mansion (center left) and in the fields (right) at George Washington's Mount Vernon estate are on display. Mike Cruse changes his daughter Olivia's diaper, while his 4 year-old son Benjamin and wife, Stephanie, fold laundry in their home in Alexandria, Va. Some immigrant families from China send their U.S.-born babies to their home country to be raised by relatives. Psychologists are studying what happens when these children return home. Follow the link in our bio for the full story. (Credit: @nicolexu_ | Nicole Xu for NPR)

What should the next president understand about YOUR life? Tell us. Jill Caldwell, of Boston, shared her response when she visited the National Mall in Washington, D.C. Tell us your story in a photo or video and include #DearWashington. (Credit: @raqzal | Raquel Zaldivar/NPR)

Stress takes a toll on our bodies. A recent study suggests stress can diminish the benefits of more healthful food choices. But experts say a range of strategies can help people cope with stress. Follow the link in our bio for the full story. (Credit: Hanna Barczyk for NPR)

You've reached the point when people stop asking you what you want to be when you grow up because you've grown up. Now, it's up to you, but how do you decide what to do with the rest of your life? Follow the link in our bio to read the full essay. (Credit: @chelseabeck.psd | Chelsea Beck/NPR)

Children at the Katwe Chess Academy learn lessons that apply to life as well as the chess board. Kids in a poor neighborhood of Kampala, Uganda learn that chess has a lot in common with life. When a team of researchers evaluated the scientific literature on brain games, they found little evidence that the products improve memory or thinking in real-world tasks. Follow the link in our bio for the full story. (Credit: Katherine Streeter for NPR)

The Brown family (left to right) Malachi, 12; Lisa Nelson-Brown; Will; and Maiyah, 7, go on a scavenger hunt during a sleepover at the National Air and Space Museum's huge annex near Washington, D.C. In a building the size of three football fields — full of airplanes, parachutes, helicopters and space capsules — there's plenty of room for activities. The kids arrived early in the evening, once all the tourists had gone, and quickly spread out over the giant space on an all-night scavenger hunt and quiz. Stops along the way included: making helicopters and learning to wave a jetliner safely into the gate. Follow the link in our bio for the full story and more photos.
