An Assyrian Christian man kisses a cross after taking communion at a church in northeastern Syria. The framed photograph shows one of at least three people killed after ISIS took about 300 people captive in March 2015. A year later, the area is no longer under ISIS control, but the Assyrian community is still scarred. Follow our profile link for the full story. (Credit: Alice Fordham/NPR)

Many Muslims feel called upon to publicly defend their faith, a faith many say is not accurately reflected in the stated or assumed motivations behind recent terrorist attacks around the world. Writer Beenish Ahmed has struggled with this responsibility all her life. The imam at Beenish's childhood mosque gave a sermon to ground the community in their faith following the attacks on Sept. 11. "That was the faith we followed, the imam said, and the one we should try to live out. I decided to take what came my way and accept it with grace — not to change anyone's minds about Islam, but because that's what my religion taught me to do. And because doing so brought me a sense of solace in a world that had come to feel so cruel." Follow our profile link to the full essay. (Credit: Angie Wang for NPR)

[4/4] At age 36, he’s rethought his whole life. Israeli Noam Chayut grew up eager to be a soldier, to defend his country and his people from its enemies. Dozens of his family members had been murdered by the Nazis, and Chayut felt he, too, was a victim of the Holocaust. “And when I was young,” he says, “the enemy could be Nazis, Arabs, Palestinians. It was a mixture of evil.” An encounter with a scared Palestinian girl meant nothing to him at the moment when it took place, back when he was a soldier. But years later, the memory returned out of nowhere and “became important,” Chayut says, “even a turning point for me,” Chayut says. “The moment she didn’t smile back, I became an occupier, a victimizer.” Noam's is one of several stories about what makes people change their minds – even in the entrenched Israeli-Palestinian conflict. Follow our profile link to learn more about his story and others’, part of @emilyharrisnpr's exploration this week of what prompts people to adopt a new perspective. (Credit: Emily Harris/NPR)

[3/4] Like many Palestinians and Israelis, Abla Masrujeh was heartened and hopeful when the two sides signed an initial peace deal in 1993. The Palestinian woman sat down with Israelis – for the first time ever! And she made friends. But now she won’t set foot in Israel, not even to visit family. 
Hear why her mind changed so drastically. It’s one of four stories in @emilyharrisnpr's Mindchangers series about people who shifted their views -- even in the entrenched Israeli-Palestinian conflict. Follow our profile link to learn more about Masrujeh's story. (Credit: Emily Harris/NPR)

[2/4] Tamar Asraf is truly at home on this hilltop in the West Bank settlement of Eli. But she never guessed she would be.  Growing up, she felt the best way to protect her beloved Israel was to give up land – the West Bank specifically – to Palestinians, in exchange for peace. “I felt like the settlers and the settlements are the worst thing that can happen to Israel - because of them, we don’t have peace,” Asraf remembers thinking. What changed her mind and made her become a settler herself? 
Asraf is one of four Israelis and Palestinians explaining their shifts in belief in @emilyharrisnpr's Mindchangers series. Follow our profile link to learn more about Asraf’s story and others’. (Credit: Emily Harris/NPR)

[1/4] Does this man look like a fighter? As a kid, Bassam Aramin sure wanted to be. He dreamed of being a general in a Palestinian army and beating back the Israeli soldiers who occupied the West Bank. When he was 17, he and his pals got a chance. They found an old rifle and hand grenades in a cave. What happened next took Aramin unexpected places and tested him in unbearable ways. 
Aramin is one of four people who tell their stories in our series about changing your mind. Follow our profile link to his full story, part of @emilyharrisnpr's exploration this week of what prompts people to adopt a new perspective. (Credit: Emily Harris/NPR)

In some places, it's called rent court or housing court. Others, eviction court. In Washington, D.C., it's known as the Landlord and Tenant Branch. This is where landlords in the city sue tenants, usually because they failed to pay the rent. Each weekday morning, dozens of people can be seen filing into the three-story courthouse where their cases will be heard. And maybe their fates decided. Follow our profile link for the full story. (Credit: Josh Kramer for NPR)

Saint Patrick, the patron saint of Ireland, was born to high status in Britain, then stolen away by pirates as a teen. It's a life story with plenty of fodder to cook up an unexpected, historically inspired menu. Follow our profile link to the full story. (Credit: @katherinethedu | Katherine Du/NPR) #stpatricksday #illustration

Katie Plas, a junior petroleum engineering major at Marietta College, studies before class. Students come from all over the world to study petroleum engineering in southern Ohio and Marietta College. In the past nearly every graduate had a good job. But as the price of oil has plummeted, companies are cutting back on production and expansion, and cutting into Marietta's placement rate. Follow our profile link for the full story and more photos. (Credit: @maddiemcgarvey | Maddie McGarvey for NPR) #education #ohio

[3/3] Saki Sato (left), 77, and Chikuyo Yokoyama, 90, are neighbors in the housing project in Fukushima city, Japan. Five years after a forced evacuation, Sato and thousands of others just like her are still in limbo. Follow our profile link for the full story and more photos. (Credit: Kosuke Okahara for NPR)

[2/3] Toru Anzai is one of the evacuees from Iitate village who has been living in temporary housing for five years in Fukushima city, Japan. He is concerned about the children's health in Fukushima after the nuclear disaster in 2011, so he is organizing trips for kids to detox in the clean air in the region of Yamaguchi. Follow our profile link for the full story and more photos. (Credit: Kosuke Okahara for NPR)

[1/3] Temporary is lasting a long time for evacuees in neat blocks of pre-fabricated housing in Fukushima city, Japan. Nearly 60,000 people still find themselves in temporary trailers after having to flee five years ago following a magnitude-9 earthquake on March 11, 2011. The tremor unleashed a tsunami and caused a nuclear disaster that contaminated soil with radiation. Rebuilding has taken so long, and public safety fears are so entrenched that the Fukushima government estimates half of the evacuees may never return. Follow our profile link for the full story and more photos. (Credit: Kosuke Okahara for NPR)

A group of young Muslim friends in Washington, D.C., meets occasionally to support each other in their work and discuss the struggles their community faces. For Muslim-Americans, there was a world before Sept. 11 and after. Now, the dual threats of extremism and atheism threaten them further. Follow our profile link to hear the full conversation and see more photos. (Credit: @btruetoyou | Brandon Chew/NPR)

Dr. Max Lebow examines the ear of 4-year-old Charlotte Anderson at Reliant Immediate Care in Los Angeles. Charlotte's mom brought her to the urgent care clinic because Charlotte was having balance problems. The majority of Americans have a primary care doctor, still a large number also seek treatment at urgent care centers, statistics show. For many people, the centers have become a bridge between the primary care doctor's office and the emergency room. Follow our profile link for the full story. (Credit: Benjamin Brian Morris for NPR) #health

Most people who drop out of college leave during the first year, and interventions haven't done much to change that. Now, campuses are coming together to try something new. Follow our profile link for the full story. (Credit: @thelajohnson | LA Johnson/NPR) #education #illustration

Last summer, a Chinese-American woman contacted NPR's Frank Langfitt with an unusual request: to help find her troubled sister, who had vanished in southwest China. A difficult journey followed. Follow our profile link to the full story. (Credit: @isabel_seliger | Isabel Seliger for NPR)

[4/4] Kids race at U.N. Protection of Civilians camp near Bentiu, South Sudan. Children make up the majority of the residents in the camp. In fact, roughly a third of the population of the Bentiu camp is under the age of five. Our profile link takes you to the full story and more photos. (Credit: David Gilkey/NPR)

[3/4] People stand in line for food rations while children play in a ditch at the U.N. Protection of Civilians camp near Bentiu, South Sudan. Food from the U.N. is distributed in what used to be a Doctors Without Borders tuberculosis hospital. One day last week several hundred people were waiting to register for food aid. Our profile link takes you to the full story and more photos. (Credit: David Gilkey/NPR)

[2/4] Tavitha Nyaluk, 26, has lived in the U.N. Protection of Civilians site near Bentiu, South Sudan, for two years. She came because she was afraid soldiers might attack her family. Now Nyaluk is afraid to leave, worried she wouldn't be able to feed her children. Our profile link takes you to the full story and more photos. (Credit: David Gilkey/NPR)

[1/4] The destruction of the city of Bentiu is part of the new phase of South Sudan's two-year-old civil war. Most of the direct fighting has stopped. But in this country of roughly 10 million, the war forced an estimated 2.5 million South Sudanese from their homes. Our profile link takes you to the full story and more photos. (Credit: David Gilkey/NPR)

Several recent integration efforts focus more on family income diversity as the driver of public school integration. The potential benefits of a diverse environment are striking, but they're not always guaranteed. Follow our profile link for the full story. (Credit: @thelajohnson | LA Johnson/NPR) #education #illustration

[4/4] These Greek grandmothers, Militsa Kamvis and Maritsa Mavrapidi, are known as celebrities in Lesbos, Greece. When migrants landed in boats outside their village, Kamvis and Mavrapidi offered clothes, homemade cheese pies and hugs. But the grandmothers say showing love to people in need doesn't make someone a hero. It just means they're human. Follow our profile link for more reporting on the migrant crisis in Greece. (Credit: @kainazamaria | Kainaz Amaria/NPR)

[3/4] Sabine Choucair is from Lebanon and a founder of the group, Clown Me In, where she performs as part of #clownswithoutborders. The kids love Sabine. They've suffered so much on their journey, but then here comes this clown, dancing, singing, bear-hugging just to entertain them. Follow our profile link for more reporting on the migrant crisis in Greece. (Credit: @kainazamaria | Kainaz Amaria/NPR)

[2/4] Dominic "Mimmo" Vella, 44, is a speedboat pilot from Malta who has helped rescue countless migrants on the Aegean Sea. Mimmo decided to work for MOAS (a non-profit Migrant rescue service) because he got tired of seeing children drown in the Aegean. He still remembers one rescue where three children had drowned. He choked up when he talked about them and called one boy a little angel. Follow our profile link for more reporting on the migrant crisis in Greece. (Credit: @kainazamaria | Kainaz Amaria/NPR)

CIA Director John Brennan sat down with NPR for a wide-ranging interview at the agency's headquarters in Langley, Va. "I don't know when I will leave CIA," Brennan said. "There are three people who determine that: the president, whether it's this one or the next one, myself, and my wife, who's been my partner for the last 37 years. She gets a vote in this, and I think will vote." Our profile link takes you to the full interview. (Credit: Ariel Zambelich/NPR)

No alarm. No school bus. No problem. Thanks to a school's laptop program, everyone takes a virtual lesson from home. Follow our profile link for the full story. (Credit: @thelajohnson | LA Johnson/NPR) #education #illustration

Karriem Saleem El-Amin of Baltimore is one of the more than 130 prisoners serving life sentences for violent crimes who were released on probation following a landmark ruling by Maryland's highest court. None of the affected prisoners has re-offended so far. But that's no comfort to angry families of their victims. Our profile link takes you to the full story. (Credit: @btruetoyou | Brandon Chew/NPR)

'Aedes aegypti' is the primary mosquito responsible for spreading the Zika virus that's sweeping through Latin America and the Caribbean. It's an ideal spreader of disease — from its attraction to trash to its habit of sipping blood from lots of people in one feeding spree. Follow our profile link to learn more. (Credit: Matthew Twombly for NPR)

Virtual reality, video chatting and other innovations are helping international students and colleges tell whether they're a good match. Follow our profile link for the full story. (Credit: @thelajohnson | LA Johnson/NPR) #tech #illustration #education

[3/3] Earl and Jeneyah McDonald pose for a portrait with their sons Justice, 6, and Josiah, 2, at their home in Flint. The McDonalds have had to teach their sons that the water is poison and not to go near it or use it. "I will never trust this water ever again," Jeneyah says, shaking her head. Our profile link takes you to the full story. (Credit: @lauramcdermottphoto | Laura McDermott for NPR) #flint

[2/3] Jeneyah McDonald unloads cases of bottled water to take to her godbrother Brent Diggs, who is handicapped and often unable to pick up water himself, at his home in Flint, Mich. It takes Jeneyah about an hour to visit several water pick up stops each day to get enough water for her family. She has no idea how many weeks or months this daily routine will have to continue. Our profile link takes you to the full story. (Credit: @lauramcdermottphoto | Laura McDermott for NPR) #flint

[1/3] Jeneyah McDonald stands amid cases of bottled water in the kitchen of her home in Flint, Mich. Before water donations arrived in Flint, McDonald says, she spent an estimated $100 out of her $300 weekly grocery bill buying safe water for her family. The problems with high lead levels in Flint, Mich.'s water started in April 2014, when the city switched water sources and began drawing its supply from the Flint River. The new water was harder, and government officials allowed it to corrode the city's pipes, leaching lead and other toxins into the tap water. Our profile link takes you to the full story. (Credit: @lauramcdermottphoto | Laura McDermott for NPR) #flint

Most breast cancer cases are in women, so treatment and support are geared toward them. About 2,600 men are diagnosed annually and they can feel isolated when entering a world of pink. Our profile link takes you to the full story. (Credit: Maria Fabrizio for NPR)

NPR's Brazil Correspondent Lourdes Garcia-Navarro performs with the Vila Isabel Samba School during Carnival in Rio de Janeiro. Our profile link takes you to a short video of the performance. (Credit: André Vieira for NPR) #carnival #brazil

Last week, Benjamin McCrumade won his town’s annual surfing championship in Robertsport, a sleepy village town a few hours up the coast from Monrovia, Liberia. The championship was canceled last year because of the Ebola outbreak, and he and his fellow surfers were excited to compete again. "We can't let people say, 'Oh, y'all got good waves in Liberia but you don't surf them,' " McCrumade says. "I'm going to surf and enjoy my waves because it's my country's nature. That's what I love about surfing.” Follow our profile link to the full story. (Credit: Carielle Doe for NPR) #surfing #liberia

Noel Melecio, 15, talks with YMCA outreach worker John Vergara during a recent Urban Warriors session. In parts of Chicago, violence is unavoidable, with effects similar to being in a war zone. The Urban Warriors program connects kids with veterans who may understand what they've been through. "Anywhere else anybody would just tell you, 'Oh, you'll be OK,' or they'll pat you on the back or something. But them, they like get into your feelings and help you sort them out," Melecio says. Our profile link takes to you to more photos and the full story. (Credit: Alyssa Schukar for NPR) #chicago

Harry Rubenstein is the chair of the political history division at the Smithsonian Museum of American History in Washington, D.C. He's standing in a room that's packed with about 100,000 different items from previous presidential elections. The collection, he says, ranges "from a little bit before the American Revolution, to probably last week." Our profile link takes you to the full story and more photos. (Credit: @btruetoyou | Brandon Chew/NPR) #politics #history #washingtondc

Tom Wall listens to violinist Tim Fain perform during the Make Room concert at Wall's apartment in Annapolis, Md. The concert is a fundraiser to help Wall pay his rent and shine a light on the growing lack of affordable housing. Our profile link takes you to the full story. (Credit: @btruetoyou | Brandon Chew/NPR) #maryland

The New World Mall features an underground food court that offers a smorgasbord of Chinese dishes. Take the train to the Queens neighborhood of Flushing, and you'll find newcomers who are reshaping the largest Chinese community of any city outside of Asia. Our profile link takes you to the full story. (Credit: @cont4ct | Cameron Robert/NPR)

This week, the Obama administration banned the use of solitary confinement for juveniles. Valerie Jarrett, senior adviser to President Obama, spoke with NPR about the push for changes in the criminal justice system. Our profile link takes you to the full interview. (Credit: @kainazamaria | Kainaz Amaria/NPR)

When a body goes unclaimed in Boston, it may receive a burial at a city cemetery. Students at Roxbury Latin boys' school are among those who volunteer to be pallbearers for people they've never met. Our profile link takes you to the full story. (Credit: @kayanaszymczak | Kayana Szymczak for NPR) #boston #volunteer

Kevin Schiller walks his dog, Maxine, near his apartment. After working for Macy's department stores as a building engineer for 21 years, a workplace accident has left Kevin Schiller unable to work since 2010. Since the accident Schiller has persistent headaches, memory loss, disorientation and extreme sensitivity to bright light and loud sound. Schiller, 54, is among 1.5 million workers in Texas and Oklahoma who don't have state-regulated workers' compensation to turn to when they're injured on the job. Millions more may join them as more states consider giving employers the right to opt out of state workers' comp systems. Our profile link takes you to the full story. (Credit: Brandon Thibodeaux for NPR)

[4/4] In one year Stephen Ritz and his students planted some 20,000 bulbs across New York City. The lesson, Ritz says, is that a seed well-planted can grow into something beautiful anywhere. Our profile link takes you to the full story. (Credit: @elissanad | Elissa Nadworny/NPR) #education #bronx

[3/4] In the afternoon, Stephen Ritz hosts a fourth-grade cooking class. On the menu: vegetarian chili. Everyone gets a cooking hat in Ritz's cooking class. The kids are told to hold a knife like they're shaking a hand, and hold the pepper with their fingers curled into a bear claw. Our profile link takes you to the full story. (Credit: @elissanad | Elissa Nadworny/NPR) #education #bronx

[2/4] Stephen Ritz calls his Bronx classroom his National Health, Wellness and Learning Center. It's got tower gardens, gleaming cabinets and counters, an industrial sink and a new, mobile cooking station. Ritz's goal: send students home with 100 bags of fresh, school-grown fruits and vegetables a week, 50 weeks a year. Our profile link takes you to the full story. (Credit: @elissanad | Elissa Nadworny/NPR) #education #bronx

[1/4] Stephen Ritz founded the nonprofit Green Bronx Machine, planting community gardens all over the Bronx. "What we're seeing is kids coming in here, getting excited about healthy food — about vegetables. About beans. Who knew beans could be so exciting, but they are!" Our profile link takes you to the full story. (Credit: @elissanad | Elissa Nadworny/NPR) #education #bronx

Anna Matthews sleds down the Capitol lawn with her dog Cody in Washington, D.C., on Sunday. Follow along with our winter storm coverage via the link in our profile. (Credit: Ariel Zambelich/NPR) #❄️ #washingtondc

Baltimore residents participate in a snowball fight on Sunday. The winter storm brought more than two feet of snow to Baltimore, according to the Weather Channel. Follow along with our coverage via the link in our profile. (Credit: Emily Bogle/NPR) #❄️ #baltimore

People take advantage of a break in the blizzard to wander down Rhode Island Avenue in Washington, D.C. Snow continues to fall across the east coast, and it's anticipated to continue through Sunday in some regions. Follow along with our coverage via the link in our profile. (Credit: Ariel Zambelich/NPR) #snow #🌨

High lead levels in Flint, Mich.'s water has led President Obama to declare a state of emergency, as criticism mounts that the problem has not been handled promptly. "The people weren't put first, the health of the people was not put before profit and money," Flint Mayor Karen Weaver says in an interview with NPR. Our profile link takes you to the full interview. (Credit: Ariel Zambelich/NPR) #flint #michigan #portrait

In the Navajo culture, teachers are revered as "wisdom keepers," entrusted with the young to help them grow and learn. This is how Tia Tsosie Begay (center) approaches her work as a fourth-grade teacher at a small public school on the outskirts of Tucson, Ariz. Our profile link takes you to the full story. (Credit: @elissanad | Elissa Nadworny/NPR) #arizona #education

Hillary Clinton says a new report that some emails on her private server exceeded the "Top Secret" classification is "an effort to inject" controversy into her campaign. Our profile link takes you to the interview. (Credit: Ariel Zambelich/NPR)

[3/3] Pastor Robert Salazar, center, prays before giving his sermon at the "Cruising for Jesus" mission of Tijuana, Mexico. Salazar was a U.S. Marine in the mid-1990s. He got out hooked on drugs and ran into trouble with the law. After a robbery conviction, Salazar was deported in 2005 — dropped at the Tijuana border at 3 a.m. He did all right, though. Salazar found religion and started his church, which also runs a men's drug-rehab shelter nearby to help deported veterans. Our profile link takes you to the full story. (Credit: David Gilkey/NPR)

[2/3] Hector Barajas washes the dishes in the Deported Veteran Support House, also known as The Bunker. Barajas has been running the shelter in Tijuana, Mexico, for about five years. "When they'd deport any veterans, they would usually end up in my apartment. That's the system we had," Barajas says. Our profile link takes you to the full story. (Credit: David Gilkey/NPR)

[1/3] Former U.S. Marine Daniel Torres stands outside the Deported Veteran Support House, known as the The Bunker, in eastern Tijuana, Mexico. During World War II, thousands of Americans lied about their age to enlist in the military. During the Iraq war, Daniel Torres lied about something else. "I didn't want to be just another Mexican living in the U.S. I wanted to say I'd done something for the country," said Torres. He deployed to Iraq, near Fallujah, in 2009. When his unit came home and started gearing up for a tour in Afghanistan, Torres lost his wallet. When he tried to get his ID replaced, his story came apart and was later deported to Mexico. Our profile link takes you to the full story. (Credit: David Gilkey/NPR)

Owner of No Grease Barber Shop in Charlotte, N.C., Damian Johnson, finishes up Sam Chaney's haircut. Barbershops have long been a place for political talk and it's important to Johnson to keep that tradition alive. When asked whom Johnson likes best in the presidential race, he says he hasn't committed to any one candidate yet. Amid major economic development and an immigration influx, a trip to Charlotte reveals trends within the Republican Party that are taking place across cities facing similar issues. Our profile link takes you to the full story. (Credit: Logan Cyrus for NPR) #nc #politics

"In 1982, when I washed up on NPR's doorstep looking for a job, I started a pickup basketball game. It endures to this day. That's right, we are in our 33rd season, which makes me too old to still be playing ... and yet, somehow, I still am," NPR's Peter Breslow on his long-running pickup basketball game in Washington, D.C. Our profile link takes you to the full commentary. (Credit: @walker_niki | Niki Walker/NPR) #🏀

Returning to school after a few weeks away is a tough transition for many kids, but it's even harder for children living in stressful homes. Our profile link takes you to the full story. (Credit: @thelajohnson | LA Johnson/NPR)

The education at the Rose City Rowing Club starts long before oars touch the water. The first lesson from head coach Nick Haley (center) is about punctuality. Afternoon practice begins at 4 o'clock sharp at this club in Portland, Ore. The next lesson is about respect. This one's a big deal at Rose City: Respect your fellow teammates, coaches, the sport itself and — today in particular — the equipment. Our profile link takes you to the full story. (Credit: David Gilkey/NPR) #rowing #portland

Tampon or pad? That's all you get when you stroll through the feminine care aisle of any big supermarket chain. But times are a changin'. This past year has been epic for menstruation, with news and social media catapulting the once hush-hush topic into the open. Our profile link takes you to the entire story. (Credit: Mouni Feddag for NPR)

Illustrator Rose Jaffe created this piece for a story about new guidance on children and screen time. “Back in college, when people were starting to spend loads of time on their phones, I just felt like everyone was holding these small computers so close to their faces that soon they would become one!” Jaffe said. Follow our link to read more about recommendations on how long children should use digital devices. (Credit: Rose Jaffe for NPR) #parenting #illustration

Stephanie Johnson teaches special education classes at Oak Canyon Junior High School in Lindon, Utah. "My joy is in the classroom," Johnson says. "When [the students] catch onto something and they have those 'a-ha' moments." From the outside, it looks like Johnson has everything under control. But that's now how she feels. "I don't know how to describe it," Johnson says. "It's just so much work." She's not talking about teaching or lesson planning or even working with disruptive students. She really likes those parts of the job. "It's all the other compliance and laws and paperwork." Our profile link takes you to the full story. (Credit: Alex Hale for NPR) #education #utah #portrait

Now that the Supreme Court is considering the issue of affirmative action in college admissions, all kinds of groups are weighing in. But we're not hearing from the people who will be most affected by the court's decision: college-bound teenagers.

NPR talked to teenagers who attend two suburban high schools near Washington, D.C.: One is majority black, and the other school has a mix of Latino, black, white and Asian students. The 16- and 17-year-olds knew little or nothing about the case that's before the Supreme Court — Fisher v. University of Texas at Austin — or about Abigail Fisher, the young woman who sued the university back in 2008. Fisher was denied admission because, she argued, the university wanted more minorities and she was white.

So here's the question we asked the students: Should college admissions decisions take race into consideration?

Anh-Thi Le, 17, is Vietnamese-American and a senior at Northwood High School, one of the most racially diverse schools in Montgomery County, Md. Anh-Thi is applying to Georgetown University and other top schools where Asians are overrepresented. Even though, says Anh-Thi, Asian kids from poor immigrant families like hers face the same daunting odds that poor black and Latino students face. "They weren't given as much guidance when it comes to college. They don't have the same resources like expensive SAT [prep] classes or educated parents who can teach them how to get into college. So, they have to work a lot harder than a white student. I don't think that's fair," Anh-Thi says.

Listen to other students talk about affirmative action via the link in our profile. (Credit: Elissa Nadworny/NPR) #education #race #teens

From Ferguson, to Baltimore, to Charleston, racially charged violence and protests dominated much of the news in 2015. While much of the country watched these events unfold, they had the deepest resonance in the cities at the center of them — going beyond the news and filtering into into family living rooms and kitchens.

That's true of Liz Alston's family in Charleston, S.C. It's a family that is deeply political — all of them have voted in every presidential election they could. But, this campaign season, the political disagreements aren't necessarily about a specific presidential candidate, but, rather, a specific issue – the rise of protests around issues of race and the Black Lives Matter movement.

NPR spent the afternoon with some of Alston's relatives, as they often do, discussing politics, race, power, and protests at her home in the historic neighborhood of Old Charleston. The conversation began with presidential politics, and quickly veered toward the protesters who interrupted a Clinton campaign event in October at a historically black college in Atlanta.

Here, LaCurtia Brown, 22, embraces Judge Richard Fields, 95, who’s affectionately known as "The Judge" to his family. LaCurtia has never attended a protest rally herself, but she agrees with the activists and understands why they're targeting Clinton now. "I think protesting is harmless. I think that they just want a voice, they want to be heard,” she said.

Listen to the entire conversation via the link in our profile. (Credit: @dustin_franz | Dustin Franz for NPR) #politics #family #blacklivesmatter

Recent scientific research hints at how the human brain is uniquely able to recognize and enjoy music. Timing in your brain is nearly everything. Our profile takes you to the full story and videos of Drake dancing, seriously. (Credit: @studioria | Maria Fabrizio for NPR) #illustration #science #🎧

Great pumpkin pie is elusive. You could end up with a soggy crust or a grainy filling. For months, reporter Maanvi Singh has been on a journey to learn the art and science of the ideal pie – a quest for custard, crust, and glory. Our profile link takes you to the full pie journey. (Credit: @mererizzo | Meredith Rizzo/NPR) #pie

Nikia Cliff II, 6, throws paper airplanes with his Major Chords for Minors piano instructor, Bruce Leaman, after the music lesson. John and Katrina Vowell used their small savings to start Major Chords in Saginaw, Mich., because they were worried about the city's youth. They provides free private music lessons — and instruments — to kids who can't afford them. Now they have 130 students and a long wait list. Our profile link takes you to the full story and more photos. (Credit: Brittney Lohmiller for NPR) #michigan #🎼

The holidays can be difficult for families dealing with Alzheimer's disease, especially if the person with the disease is the one who used to be the heart and soul of Christmas. Helen Downs (left) was diagnosed with Alzheimer's and moved in with her son seven years ago. As she slowly forgot how to make her famous yeast rolls and use her microwave, her daughter-in-law Mary (right) helped her send out greeting cards, buy presents and bake loaves of banana bread. Eventually, Mary took on the Christmas dinner, too. As Helen has declined, the Downses have had to accept a new reality. Our profile link takes you to the full story. (Credit: @mererizzo | Meredith Rizzo/NPR)

Earlier this month Ted Cruz spoke with NPR's Steve Inskeep about his plan to curb immigration of Middle Eastern refugees — and why he may disagree with but won't criticize Donald Trump. Our profile link takes you to the full interview. (Credit: Ariel Zambelich/NPR)

In an interview with NPR’s Steve Inskeep (left), President Obama says Donald Trump has found a way to play off American anxieties, some of which are "justified, but just misdirected." The president said that economic and demographic changes in the country have left a void that Trump is “exploiting during the course of his campaign." Our profile link takes you to the video interview. (Credit: Kainaz Amaria/NPR)

Kenya Barris, creator of the television show 'Black-ish' (@blackishabc), sometimes looks at his five kids in wonderment. "We're kind of taught to give your kids more than you had," Barris muses. "But in giving them more, what do they lose?" And that is the core of 'Black-ish'. Barris says that although many of the storylines from the show come directly from experiences he and his writing team have had in real life, they can also be universal. Our profile link takes you to the full story. (Credit: @meganmiller013 | Megan Miller for NPR) #television #portrait

Hand-cut paper snowflakes line the ceiling of the East Colonnade at the White House. Every year, hundreds of people apply for a chance to volunteer to decorate the White House for the holidays. All 70,000 ornaments and 8,000 snowflakes of it. Our profile link takes you to the full story and more photos. (Credit: Emily Bogle/NPR) #❄️

This week marks the 242nd anniversary of the Boston Tea Party. And this year marks the 150th anniversary of the Mad Hatter's tea party. On the surface, these two events seem to have very little in common. But if you'll follow us down the rabbit hole (via our profile link), you'll find some surprising connections. (Credit: @minniephan_ | Minnie Phan for NPR) #tea #illustration #🍵

Justice Stephen Breyer, one of the members of the nation's highest court, dropped by the NPR Politics Podcast last week for a wide-ranging conversation about the inner workings of the Supreme Court, and Washington, changing global realities and why he loved the musical "Hamilton". Our profile link takes you to the full episode. (Credit: Ariel Zambelich/NPR) #politics #portrait #podcast

Biologist Laurie Thompson holds the 4-month-old giant panda cub Bei Bei during his media debut on Wednesday at the Smithsonian National Zoo in Washington, D.C. Keepers say the cub, born in August, is developmentally on track and ahead of his older sister Bao Bao in some milestones. The cub will make his public debut on Jan. 16. Our profile link takes you to the full story and more panda photos. (Credit: @juntsuboike | Jun Tsuboike/NPR) #🐼

This is Aniket, a 15-year-old boy from Pune, India, as he waits with his younger sister, Aarati, for the rain to stop so he can walk her to school. The division of labor in his family — he sells flowers in the market, his older sister is stuck at home washing clothes and cooking dinner — is something he never thought to question. That is, until recently, when he joined an unusual class at school, run by a nonprofit group. The class taught him to be kinder and more helpful to his older sister, who must do chores while he plays outside. “The girls were doing all the work at home while the boys were allowed to go fly kites,” he recalls. “What would it feel like if I stopped doing everything for one day and only sat at home? That’s how my sister must feel,’ and that’s why I started doing work at home." Our profile link takes you to the full story. (Credit: @poulomi07 | Poulomi Basu/VII Photo for NPR) #15Girls

[4/4] Jennifer Carter, 30, stands for a portrait at the Road Home Community Winter Shelter facility in Midvale, Utah. Carter shares her space in the dormitory area (left) with her two young children. The shelter houses roughly 200 other people – all families. Carter was evicted after she had to quit her job when her work hours changed and she couldn't afford child care. Currently, she applies for at least 10 jobs a day. But Carter is worried that even if she gets a job and can leave the shelter, she might not be able to afford everything on her own – like rent, food, clothes, toiletries and utilities. Our profile link takes you to the full story. (Credit: @CayceClifford | Cayce Clifford for NPR) #utah

[3/4] Joe Ortega has been living at Grace Mary Manor for six months. Grace Mary Manor is a two-story building with hallways lined with doors to studio apartments. It's one place in Salt Lake City where chronically homeless people are placed in housing, and it provides services like counseling on site. Ortega was homeless for 20 years. Our profile link takes you to the full story. (Credit: @CayceClifford | Cayce Clifford for NPR) #utah

[2/4] Volunteers of America outreach employee Sanela Piragic regularly checks in on people in homeless encampments in South Salt Lake, Utah. The state uses a Housing First approach for the chronically homeless, where housing comes first and services follow. Our profile link takes you to the full story. (Credit: @CayceClifford | Cayce Clifford for NPR) #utah

[1/4] Over the last decade, Utah has reduced the number of chronically homeless people from nearly 2,000 to 200. The state's size and support from Mormon leaders are among the reasons for its success. Our profile link takes you to the full story. (Credit: @CayceClifford | Cayce Clifford for NPR) #utah

"Average daily attendance" has long been a trusted measure, but the number conceals an important metric in identifying kids at risk of failing or dropping out: chronic absence. Our profile link takes you to the full story. (Credit: @thelajohnson | LA Johnson/NPR) #education #illustration

Former Attorney Gen. Eric Holder's career has been a series of firsts. As the first African-American to serve as this country's top law enforcement official, he came into office in 2009 promising to rebuild the Justice Department's Civil Rights division. There, he aggressively enforced voting rights, supported same-sex marriage and became a lightning rod for criticism from conservatives. 
After stepping down as attorney general earlier this year, he returned to private practice as a partner at the law firm Covington & Burling. “When I left, we had a White House ceremony and I said I would never leave the fight and that's still the way I feel,” he said. “I’m here at a law firm that does a whole variety of things on the commercial side but my life is still going to be focused on dealing with voting rights issues.” Listen to the full interview via the link in our profile. (Credit: @juntsuboike | Jun Tsuboike/NPR) #politics #interview #portrait

Illustrator Annette Elizabeth Allen created this piece for Kate Parkinson-Morgan's personal essay on young women appreciating older ladies. "The older woman is in her golden age, and bathed in strong golden hour light in the illustration," Allen says. "I wanted to make her look really visually (not financially) rich, so there are a lot of details in the pattern of her hair and decoration in her outfit. She’s just very secure and comfortable in herself. It’s a source of almost wonder and inspiration for us younger folks who are constantly in a scramble to figure out what the heck we’re doing." Our profile link takes you to the essay. (Credit: Annette Elizabeth Allen/NPR) #GrownLadyCrush #illustration

A ramped-up reliance on coal, the most carbon-intensive fossil fuel, presents India with a profound dilemma. A third of the world's poor live in India, and the country needs massive energy to fuel new industries and jobs to pull millions out of poverty. But coal and its byproducts are hazardous to public health. Loaders, shown here, are employed to lift heavy chunks of coal onto trucks, dangerous work that exposes many to toxins. Our profile link takes you to the full story. (Credit: Julie McCarthy/NPR) #india #coal

An underground fire has been burning for at least a century, according to villagers in Boka Pahari, in the Indian state of Jharkhand. Exposure of underground coal to atmospheric oxygen causes spontaneous combustion. Coal seams burning at night in the state's Jharia coal region set off a ghostly, vermillion glow, releasing toxins including carbon dioxide, nitrogen oxides and volatile metals such as mercury. The fire, shown here in 2014, is some 200 yards from the Boka Pahari village and is said to have started when abandoned coal mines were not properly closed. Coal is king in India and some say there's little alternative. So how can this country, the world's third-largest polluter, provide energy and lift millions from poverty while trying to become "greener"? Our profile link takes you to the full story. (Credit: Johnny Haglund) #india #coal

[4/4] Blue dye floods the floor in the wet processing area at Blue Creations' factory, just outside of LA. The company specializes in putting the finishing touches on high-end jeans. To process denim, the fabric is washed using industrial machinery to get the “wash,” or color of the fabric, to exact specifications. Designers send their instructions, and employees here cut those perfect designer rips, and they iron and sand. Our profile link takes you to the full series. (Credit: John Francis Peters @jfpetersphoto for NPR) #manufacturing #LA #👖

[3/4] Fashion is a big part of LA's identity, but by the mid-'90s, the garment industry was changing, and some big factories closed and sent work overseas. One bright spot amidst this change has been high-end denim. A lot of $30 jeans are made in Mexico or China, but designer jeans almost always come from LA. They're still using local talent and expertise at places like Blue Creations, a wash house that puts finishing touches on designer jeans. Here, an employee at Blue Creations works in the wet processing area, where jeans are bleached, stone washed and treated with enzymes. Our profile link takes you to the full series. (Credit: John Francis Peters @jfpetersphoto for NPR) #manufacturing #LA #👖

[2/4] Aerospace has had its heart in LA for decades, and SpaceX is a good symbol of the future of that industry. Its headquarters in the LA suburb of Hawthorne had at one time been used to make fuselages for Boeing airplanes. Now it houses a private company that's venturing into outer space. Our profile link takes you to the full series. (Credit: Kevin Leahy/NPR) #manufacturing #california #LA

[1/4] Los Angeles is a sprawling metropolis, and it was poised to become a manufacturing giant because of its unique geography. In terms of jobs, the LA area is the biggest manufacturing hub in the country. There are a few reasons why. There is plenty of space here to build things like factories and runways. That beautiful California weather? It's actually great for testing planes year-round. As industry grew, so did an infrastructure of freeways that connects the ports to the eastern reaches of Los Angeles and San Bernardino counties, where factories had the space to expand. Our profile link takes you to the full series. (Credit: John Francis Peters @jfpetersphoto for NPR) #manufacturing #california #LA

A mural for Freddie Gray is seen at the intersection of North Mount and Presbury streets where he was arrested in April. It's been seven months since protests over the death of an unarmed black man after his arrest erupted into looting and arson, leading Baltimore's mayor to declare a curfew and call in the National Guard. Now, that unrest remains a potent backdrop as the trial begins for the first of six police officers charged in Freddie Gray's death. Our profile link takes you to the full story. (Credit: Jun Tsuboike/NPR) @juntsuboike #baltimore #freddiegray

Traveling this week? NPR's earbud.fm has a massive list of podcast recommendations including this one for the Crybabies podcast. The entire show is devoted to asking: What makes you weep? It's one of author Domingo Martinez's favorite podcasts. “It's like participating in a clever conversation with friends,” Martinez says. Head to our profile link to listen to an episode. (Credit: Annette Elizabeth Allen/NPR) #podcasts #illustration #😢

Putting on the white coat for the first time has become a rite of passage for medical students. Now some doctors want to retire white coats, despite their symbolism, because they might spread germs. Our profile link takes you to the full personal essay. (Credit: Lorenzo Gritti for NPR) @hellogritti #health

For more years than we can remember, the Friday before Thanksgiving has meant that NPR's Susan Stamberg would try to sneak a notorious and, yes, weird family recipe into NPR's coverage. And 2015 is no exception. Our profile link takes you to the recipe for Mama Stamberg's Cranberry Relish. (Credit: Ariel Zambelich & Emily Bogle/NPR) #thanksgiving #homemade #🦃

Today is World Toilet Day, a chance to think about the billions of people in the world who don't have toilets. People like writer and senior program adviser Jane Otai. When nature called, her process went like this: Walk to the stinky community toilet. Stand in line. Dance to keep from peeing. Curse the people inside for taking too long. Then repeat. Our profile link takes you to the full personal essay. (Credit: Maria Fabrizio for NPR) #globalhealth #worldtoiletday #illustration

Lydia Smith, 87, has lived in the same apartment in the Westlake neighborhood of Los Angeles for 46 years. Now that she is on a fixed income, she pays rent with the aid of Section 8 tenant-based assistance. Smith is one of the 2.6 million women aged 65 and over living at or below the poverty line. Our profile link takes you to the full story. (Credit: Megan Miller for NPR) @meganmiller013 #women #losangeles #portrait

Nathan Fields, a health outreach worker, has a knack for building trust with some of the people who distrust public officials the most. Every Thursday night you can find Fields making the rounds of Baltimore's red light district, known to locals as The Block. He talks with dancers, bouncers and anyone else passing by about preventing drug overdoses and how to stop the spread of HIV and other sexually transmitted diseases. Our profile link takes you to the full story. (Credit: Meredith Rizzo/NPR) #baltimore #health

Veterans groups, like the American Legion and Veterans of Foreign Wars, are struggling to recruit and engage younger veterans who served in the Iraq and Afghanistan wars. Our profile link takes you to the full story. (Credit: Annette Elizabeth Allen/NPR) #veterans #illustration

Jasper Barnett, a junior at Thomas Jefferson High School for Science and Technology in Alexandria, Va., looks up in the school's planetarium. NPR Ed's Tools of the Trade series examines the planetarium: a relic of the Space Age that's still found in more than 700 schools around the country. Our profile link takes you to the full story. (Credit: Elissa Nadworny/NPR) @elissanad #education #space #✨

This is the time of year subsistence farmers in western Brazil clear land by setting fires in the Amazon. Some residents say it's the only way they can make a living, but the fires are delivering another blow to the rain forest. The fires often rage uncontrolled and they are also being used more often. Go to our profile link to see more photos of the Amazon's fire season and listen to one farmer's story about trying to survive. (Credit: Kainaz Amaria/NPR) #environment #brazil

Sen. Bernie Sanders concedes that he trails Hillary Clinton for the Democratic nomination, but also notes that some polls show him doing better than Clinton in matchups against the Republicans. "Look, when we began this campaign some six months ago, I would say 80 percent of American people didn't know who Bernie Sanders was or what I stood for. We have come a very, very long way," Sanders told NPR's Morning Edition. Our profile link takes you to the full story. (Credit: Jun Tsuboike/NPR) @jtsuboike

Artist Maria Fabrizio made this illustration for a health story on how a suicide prevention program in Detroit achieved a zero suicide rate among its members. "Suicide prevention is such a heavy topic that I wanted to find a way to show the struggle through the potential jump,” Fabrizio says. "I used the hands to show the program’s support, and the quiet, starry background is meant to echo the loneliness of the situation.” Follow our profile link to read about this Detroit program's efforts to prevent suicide. (Credit: Maria Fabrizio for NPR) @studioria #illustration #health

Backpacks and textbooks are a match made in heaven. But not too long ago, students walked to school carrying their books in their arms. Our profile link takes you to NPR Ed's illustrated history of backpacks. (Credit: LA Johnson/NPR) @thelajohnson #backpack #illustration #education

You can participate too: Snap a picture of your first, current or favorite backpack and tag it #nprbackpack

[3/3] Principal Nikkia Rowe (left) laughs with students as they head to the cafeteria for lunch at the Renaissance Academy High School in Baltimore. Since Renaissance Academy's mentors started last spring, suspensions are way down and grades are up. But Rowe says the real measure of success may not come until next summer. That's the time when students don't have this safe place to be every day. For now, she's trying to find the money for more mentors. Our profile link takes you to the full story. (Credit: Jun Tsuboike/NPR) @jtsuboike #Baltimore #HighSchool #Mentors

[2/3] Marcus Taylor (left) plays basketball with Renaissance Academy High School students during gym class in Baltimore. A lot of the mentors' work comes after hours. Taylor let one student stay with him a couple of nights — with a parent's knowledge — when things were bad at home. Cooper says a boy texted him recently, wanting to talk. "And I called him, and I was on the phone with him for an hour and I really didn't say too much," Cooper says. "He just talked, because that's all he wanted, was somebody to listen to him." Our profile link takes you to the full story. (Credit: Jun Tsuboike/NPR) @jtsuboike #Baltimore #HighSchool #Mentors

[1/3] Antwon Cooper (left) helps Renaissance Academy High School student Julius Barne, 15, during a group activity in a history class in Baltimore. Cooper is one of four African-American men hired last year to mentor 20 male students each. The mentors help with classwork for those who need it. They step in if a student acts out. They offer hugs if someone's upset. They also help get kids to class, which turns out to be a surprising challenge. Our profile link takes you to the full story. (Credit: Jun Tsuboike/NPR) @jtsuboike #Baltimore #HighSchool #Mentors

It's been a year since thousands of unaccompanied minors surged into the U.S., overwhelming some school districts. These children, many of whom don't speak English and have lived through violence, trauma and abuse, pose a serious challenge to schools. Some districts weren't ready. Oakland, Calif., was. Our profile link takes you to the full story. (Credit: @thelajohnson/NPR) #education #oakland #illustration

As part of our series, “The Changing Lives of Women,” NPR asked White House correspondent Tamara Keith to share a photo of a woman she admires. Tamara says: "I cover the executive branch along with two colleagues. But Nina Totenberg does the judicial branch by herself and she does it with aplomb. Nina has broken so many stories, it’s unbelievable. She breaks down #SCOTUS argument and decisions like no one else (and those voices!!). And I’ll let you in on a little secret, Nina is hilarious.” (Credit: Kainaz Amaria/NPR)

Who’s your #GrownLadyCrush? On this #wcw, share a photo of a woman a generation ahead of you – a boss, a neighbor, your grandmother -- with the hashtag, and tell us why she stands out.

[2/2] Durga holds up part of her younger sister's wedding dress. Durga and her two younger sisters are all childbrides and were all married on the same day. In rural villages in India, it costs the same amount to marry off one daughter as it does to marry off all of them. While arranged marriage is common in India, Durga was not happy with the husband chosen for her. He was much older and less educated. She hasn't yet gone to live with her husband and is trying to get her marriage annulled. Our profile link takes you to the full story. (Credit: @poulomi07/Poulomi Basu/VII Photo) #india #education 
Take part in our social media campaign. What was the hardest thing about being 15? Tell us using the hashtag #15Girls.

[1/2] Nimmu is 15 years old. She comes from a rural village in northern India, and she's been married since she was 10. She's trying to change her fate by attending a boarding school run by a charity called the Veerni Institute. The charity tries to make a deal with parents: We'll give your girls a free education in the city if you delay sending them to live with their husbands. Nimmu isn't looking to get out of her arranged marriage, but she does want to graduate and get a job first. That way, she says, her in-laws won't be able to boss her around. Our profile link takes you to the full story. (Credit: @poulomi07/Poulomi Basu/VII Photo) #india #education

Take part in our social media campaign. What was the hardest thing about being 15? Tell us using the hashtag #15Girls.

[4/4] Omar Al-Awad stands his daughter, Taiba, in their new home in Toledo, Ohio. When the Awads arrived in Toledo, they discovered something incredible: A family they'd been friends with in their hometown in Syria and was in the same refugee camp in Jordan, had arrived in Toledo just three days earlier. Omar the carpenter talks with Hilal the barber. Their children play together — just as they did in Syria, and in Jordan. Our profile link takes you to the full story. (Credit: David Gilkey/NPR) #Syria #Ohio #Toledo

[3/4] The city of Toldeo, Ohio, is home to eight Syrian refugee families. While some locals are concerned about their assimilation and tax dollars being spent on refugees from abroad, Toledo Mayor Paula Hicks-Hudson has no patience for these arguments. “By helping them we're helping everyone. We're a community, and so you don't carve out one individual group from another individual group," Mayor Hicks-Hudson said. Our profile link takes you to the full story. (Credit: David Gilkey/NPR) #Syria #Ohio #Toledo

[2/4] Hiyam Al-Awad watches as her family of five gets ready for school in Toledo, Ohio. Fewer than 2,000 Syrians have come to the U.S., though the war has displaced more than 12 million since it began in 2011. The refugees in America are scattered widely across more than 20 different states. So far, eight families have come to Toledo. The Awad family is the newest. Our profile link takes you to the full story. (Credit: David Gilkey/NPR) #Syria #Ohio #Toledo

[1/4] Omar Al-Awad holds his daughter, Taiba, at the playground near their family's new home in Toledo, Ohio. Awad is a carpenter from the Syrian city of Homs where his house and business were destroyed by the war. His family spent two years at a refugee camp in Jordan, and after many exams and paperwork, arrived in Toledo in September. Our profile link takes you to the full story. (Credit: David Gilkey/NPR) #Syria #Ohio #Toledo

Studies show high rates of teacher turnover — especially among minorities. One researcher is trying to figure out why and how schools can reverse the trend. Our profile link takes you to the full story. (Credit: @thelajohnson/NPR) #education #teachers #illustration

A drug that's already approved for treating leukemia appears to dramatically reduce symptoms in people who have Parkinson's disease with dementia, or a related condition called Lewy body dementia. A pilot study of 12 patients given small doses of nilotinib found that movement and mental function improved in all of the 11 people who completed the six-month trial, researchers reported Saturday at the Society for Neuroscience meeting in Chicago. One of the patients in the pilot study Alan Hoffman, shown with his wife Nancy at their home in Dumfries, Va., found that his Parkinson's symptom improved when he took the cancer drug. Our profile link takes you to the full story. (Credit: @claireeclaire/Claire Harbage for NPR) #health

Madalitso Mulando (center) knew what she needed to finish tenth grade at her public school in Zambia: $150. But the 15-year-old's parents couldn’t afford it. So Mulando decided to take a refresher course in the art of negotiation offered by two Harvard professors. She vowed to use her new skills to do some fundraising with her extended family. "If you want to ask something, you need to tell them what you want," Mulando says. Get her full story in the profile link. (Credit:@samreinders/Samantha Reinders for NPR) #15Girls #Zambia #Harvard 
Take part in our social media campaign. What was the hardest part about being 15? Tell us using the hashtag #15Girls.

It's not uncommon to hear claims that young people these days have higher rates of mental health issues than in the past. But the data doesn't back that up. So why do millennials get a bad rap? Mitch Prinstein, a psychologist at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, thinks people get that impression because milliennials are full of angst. That's not new. But unlike past generations, millennials like to broadcast their angst. "Millennials are certainly using social media in a way that we haven't seen with other generations," Prinstein says. "They're not as shy about sharing their anxieties online." Our profile link takes you to the full story. (Credit: Katherine Streeter for NPR) #millenials #mentalhealth #illustration

Parents who are uneasy about their own math skills often worry about how best to teach the subject to their kids. Well ... there's an app for that. Tons of them, in fact. And a study published this week in the journal Science suggests that at least one of them works pretty well for elementary school children and math-anxious parents. Our profile link takes you to the full story. (Credit: @thelajohnson/NPR) #math #education #➗

During the month of October, NPR Goats and Soda is on a mission to capture the collective experience of being 15 around the world through social media with the hashtag #15Girls. Yasmine San Pedro, 23, shared this photo and said, "the hardest thing for me was growing up without my mom. She had two jobs and so I spent a lot of time at my aunt's house." // Join the discussion by posting a photo of yourself as a teen, with the answer to this question: What was the hardest thing about being 15? No answer is too big or too small — everyone has a story to tell. Share your answer on Instagram by tagging @NPR with the hashtag #15Girls. Make sure to include your name, location and current age, and if you're posting a group photo, tell us which person you are. We'll profile our favorite submissions on NPR's Goats and Soda blog. More details about this action in the profile link.

It's decorative gourd season and Cinderella pumpkins just don't cut it for fall decor anymore. These wing gourds are among the new wave of eye-catching pumpkins, gourds and squash that are making places look more festive this autumn. Our profile link takes you to more gourd-geous photos and the full story. (Credit: Ariel Zambelich/NPR) #gourds #fall #🍂

This is Mimi, 15. In her country of El Salvador, there is so much gang-related violence that someone dies on average every hour -- and girls are often caught in the middle. Mimi lives in a neighborhood completely controlled by gangs and has few options for survival. She can hide from them, or give in. 
To get out of the house but stay out of trouble, she volunteers for a rescue squad once a week -- something she’s been doing since she was 10. As a paramedic, she likes being able to help people who are victims of the gangs. "It feels good to be somebody else's shield,” she says. Get her full story in the profile link. (Credit: @encarni_pin/Encarni Pindado for NPR) #15girls #ElSalvador

Apple has long touted the power and design of its devices, but recently the world's most valuable company has been emphasizing another feature: privacy. That's no small matter when many users store important private data on those devices: account numbers, personal messages, photos. In an interview, Apple CEO Tim Cook told NPR about how the company protects its customers' data, and how it uses — or doesn't use — that information. Our profile link takes you to the full interview. (Credit: Ariel Zambelich/NPR) #apple #tech #portrait

Paula and Phillip Dupont in Louisiana loved their mutt Melvin so much they jumped at the chance to replicate him. So a couple of years ago, when Melvin was about 9 and starting to show his age, the Duponts turned to a lab in South Korea. Even though the process would cost them $100,000, the couple decided to do it. Melvin is gone now, but he has left behind two clones, Ken and Henry. Our profile link takes you to the full story. (Credit: @edmundfountain for NPR) #science #dogs #louisiana

[4/4] Mohammed Eh'tai, a recent refugee from Syria, brought only his phone, his ID and a stack of certificates — his college degree in accounting, his master's in management — with him to Germany. Eh'tai had to flee Syria, leaving behind his wife and 2-year-old daughter. He now shares a two-bedroom apartment with five other Syrian men. Eh'tai wants to bring his family to Germany, but eventually he wants to return to Syria and help rebuild the country he was forced to flee. Our profile link takes you to the full story. (Credit: David Gilkey/NPR) #syria #germany

[3/4] Syrian refugees stand outside the Pentagon apartments in New Hardenberg, Germany, where they are temporally being housed. Germany is expecting at least 800,000 migrants this year alone, and Germans are struggling with the changes they bring. Our profile link takes you to the full story. (Credit: David Gilkey/NPR) #syria #germany

[2/4] About an hour outside Berlin is the town of Seelow, in former East Germany, population about 5,600. At the end of World War II, Seelow was the site of one of the last stands of Hitler's army and one of the biggest battles on German soil. Seelow Mayor Jorg Schroder says older Germans, who lived through the flood of refugees who came at the end of that war, are more open to the migrants arriving now from the Mideast. Germany re-invented itself after World War II, and again after the re-unification of East and West. Now, as its population changes, the country is re-inventing itself again. Our profile link takes you to the full story. (Credit: David Gilkey/NPR) #germany

[1/4] Refugees and migrants wait at the Regional Office for Health and Welfare in Berlin for food and a turn to start the paperwork to apply for asylum. Germany, always aware of its history of war, is taking in tens of thousands fleeing war and poverty. Many Germans have welcomed the newcomers, but some are struggling with the changes they bring. Our profile link takes you to the full story. (Credit: David Gilkey/NPR) #germany #berlin

Choreographer John Heginbotham met Baryshnikov when he was a dancer with the Mark Morris Dance Group. He now has his own dance company, which rehearses at the center. Heginbotham says this creative laboratory is really a gift from Baryshnikov to other artists: "He could've just been a great ballet dancer, but he is such a curious and investigative person that he has taken that and put it into creating work and helping other people create work. He betters himself all the time and he encourages us to do that too." Our profile link takes you to the full story. (Credit: @lovebryan for NPR) #dance #art #baryshnikov

Mikhail Baryshnikov's idea was to build a place where artists from different disciplines would come together. He had no interest in it being dance-only. Vocalist and songwriter Somi and guitarist Liberty Ellman rehearse in one of the light-filled studios at the center, which overlooks the Hudson River. ""This is such a glorious space because you've got these high windows and you're surrounded by the city,"" she says. ""And being in the middle of New York, right, it's like you're in the middle of possibility."" Our profile link takes you to the full story. (Credit: @lovebryan for NPR) #dance #art #baryshnikov

As one of the greatest ballet dancers in history, Mikhail Baryshnikov has captivated audiences around the world. He was also the artistic director of American Ballet Theatre, has danced to his own heartbeat, had a run as Carrie Bradshaw's part-time lover on HBO's "Sex and the City," and so much more. Today, at 67, Baryshnikov is still creating art of all kinds around the world. And on Monday, he celebrated the 10th anniversary of the Baryshnikov Arts Center, a space he created to give artists the freedom to explore and take risks. (Credit: @lovebryan for NPR) #dance #art #baryshnikov

Whatever the old adage might warn, there is a bit of merit to judging a book by its cover — if only in one respect: the blurb. Those snippets of praise on book covers have been around for over 150 years (at least). But how do they get there — and why? The answers are more complicated, and *compelling*, than you might think. Our profile link takes you to the full story. (Credit: Annette Elizabeth Allen/NPR) #books #illustration #📖

Here's the basic difference between the United States, Russia and Iran: The U.S. wants Syrian President Bashar Assad to go. Russia and Iran, Assad's allies, want him to stay.  Over the weekend, Iran's president, Hassan Rouhani, met with NPR in New York, where he will be attending the United Nations General Assembly. Through an interpreter, Rouhani argued that, where Syria is concerned, the most important issue for everyone is destroying ISIS. "The issue of stability and security in the region is of utmost importance for us," he emphasizes.  Americans may not like Syria's government, he says, but Iran needs to prop it up to avoid a dangerous leadership vacuum. If Assad goes now, Rouhani says, extremists will step in. The link in our profile takes you to the full interview. (Credit: @bryanthomasphoto for NPR) #iran #syria #international

The first episode of our new podcast, Hidden Brain, explores switchtracking: a common pattern in conversations you'll be accusing your partner of in no time! Host  Shankar Vedantam explores what happens when two people think they are talking about the same thing, but in reality are speeding down separate tracks. It usually doesn't end well. Follow the link in our profile to hear the full episode. (Illustration: @hannabarczyk for NPR) #socialscience #communication #illustration

Patricia Briceno waves the Peruvian and Vatican flags at the papal parade in DC. Briceno says many Peruvian Catholics support Pope Francis, the first pope from Latin America. "We have this special love for him, because he's one of us." (Credit: @jtsuboike/NPR) #PopeFrancis  #PopeInDC #PopeInUS
Spectators welcome Pope Francis as he makes his way down Constitution Avenue during the papal parade. (Credit: @jtsuboike/NPR) #PopeFrancis  #PopeInDC #PopeInUS
Rafael Xeleya, left, and Lucas Jefferson make posters for Pope Francis while waiting for the papal parade. They have been awake since 4 a.m. (Credit: @jtsuboike/NPR) #PopeFrancis #PopeInDC #PopeInUS

Early birds are claiming their spots at the Ellipse for the Papal Parade this morning. Washington, D.C. is Pope Francis' first stop in his visit to the U.S. (Credit: @jtsuboike/NPR) #PopeFrancis #PopeInDC #PopeInUS

This border police station looks directly out onto the Western Wall plaza, right on to the flashpoint of conflict. To the left is the Western Wall, the holiest site in Judaism. Just above is another broad plaza, the place Jews call the Temple Mount and Muslims call the Noble Sanctuary; it’s a sacred spot for both faiths. The covered, elevated path in the background is the only route Jews or tourists can take into the sanctuary. (Photo by @emilyharrisnpr/NPR)  #international #Jerusalem #security

Israeli border police are a major part of the forces in the Old City. Here, a few officers lounge in the building that the border police have used since 1967, when Israel conquered East Jerusalem. It is a former madrasa, or school, built in 1329 by Emir Sayf al-Din Tankiz, who was a regional ruler under the medieval Mamluk Sultanate. Arabic writing is still engraved on the walls, and the Israeli flag hangs from the high ceiling. (Photo by @emilyharrisnpr/NPR) #international #Jerusalem #security

Clashes between Palestinians and Israeli security forces spiked this week in Jerusalem, including in the Old City, which is a labyrinth of ancient stone streets, homes and shops that’s less than a half-mile square. This tiny portion of Jerusalem is under heavy surveillance, sprinkled with hundreds of cameras – many of which were installed in 2000 in preparation for Pope John Paul II’s visit. The cameras remain, and here, inside the “screen room” in a gated police compound, dozens of screens pull in video for the police to monitor. (Photo by @emilyharrisnpr/NPR)

NPR International Correspondent Emily Harris got a behind-the-scenes look at the Israeli police operation in Jerusalem’s Old City during a security tour that took her into places that are off-limits to the public, and generally hard to access even for journalists. Today, we’re sharing some highlights from that tour, but you can follow @emilyharrisnpr for more of her take on daily life in Jerusalem. #international #Jerusalem #security

All over the country, high school graduates are making the jump to college. They're getting to know their roommates, buying supplies, and saying tearful goodbyes to parents. It's a stressful time for any family, but for the growing number of students dealing with mental health issues, it can be a terrifying transition. Sometimes it raises the question: is college really the best option? Our profile link takes you to the full story. (Credit: LA Johnson/NPR) #college #health #illustration

Our Lady Queen of Angels, a Catholic church in New York City's East Harlem neighborhood, closed in 2007, but parishioners still congregate outside the parish for service every Sunday. Churches across the Northeast and Midwest, like Our Lady Queen of Angels, have seen declining parish growth since 1965. "You have beautiful structures in New York and Philadelphia and in Cleveland — all the urban areas that appear to be dying out," says Mary Gautier, a researcher who studies Catholic demographic trends. "The population is decreasing. The people that are in the pews are old, elderly and not being replaced by younger generations." Our profile link takes you to the full story. (Credit: Christopher Gregory for NPR) #religion #nyc #neighborhood

[3/3] Nationwide, 20 percent of graduating seniors in 2012 who went to college chose a private, and more expensive college education. Evan Bonham selected NYU's Tisch School of the Arts to study music production. He has about $75,000 in loans, and looking back, he wishes he had talked more about the cost of college. "Now that I'm getting ready to graduate, the debt is really starting to creep up on me," he said. Go to our profile link to hear other students' perspectives. (Credit: @alexwelshphoto for NPR) #college #nyc #education

[2/3] Going to college today is a very different experience than it once was. The cost has soared, and the recession cut into many of the assets that were supposed to pay for it. Nancy Chen chose to go to community college at Montgomery College in Maryland. She is majoring in nursing with the career goal of becoming either a nurse or firefighter. "I accumulated no debt from school, while I see my friends from high school accumulate debt," Chen said. Go to our profile link to hear other students' perspectives. (Credit: @elissanad/NPR) #college #maryland #education

[1/3] Four years ago, members of the high school class of 2012 were deciding where and how to go to college. Several factors weighed heavily: cost, the student experience, prestige and the prospect of a job after graduation. Nearly 40 percent of their classmates nationwide who pursued a higher education chose a four-year state college or university. Karie Cheung chose the University of Maryland, "because both my parents didn't get the experience of college ... I just wanted to have that traditional, live-in-the-dorm freshman year, go to all the orientations." Go to our profile link to hear other students' perspectives. (Credit: @elissanad/NPR) #college #maryland #education

Researchers have been tracking Jose Arriaga since he started preschool, waiting for the day he would start ninth grade. Jose is now a freshman at Booker T. Washington High School, a selective public school in Tulsa, Okla. A new study finds impressive academic gains from Tulsa's highly praised preschool program now that its first graduates, including Jose, are beginning high school. Our profile link takes you to the full story. (Credit: Kenneth M. Ruggiano for NPR) #tulsa #education #backtoschool

Many in the wine and beer industry claim women have a keener sense of smell, and thus taste, than men have. Sensory scientists who've tackled this topic say there's something to this claim. Our profile link takes you to the full story. (Credit: Maria Fabrizio for NPR) #science #drinks #🍷

Cattle rancher Craig Vejraska pours out feed while checking on his cattle in a smokey field in Cox Meadow, as the Okanogan Complex fires burn outside Omak, Wash., on Aug. 26. More than 1,000 square miles of wildfires are burning in Washington state. In the isolated Okanogan Valley, where power and phone lines have burned, cattle ranchers are doing what they can to spare herds. Our profile link takes you to the full story. (Credit: @iancbates for NPR) #wildfires #ranching #OkanoganValley

[3/3] Joel Munguia (center), owner of Chino's, a barbershop in Kenner, La., sits with his nephew, Waldyn Munguia (left), as they have a laugh outside on the waiting benches at the shop. Munguia came to New Orleans from Honduras in 2005 after Katrina and opened his dream shop for Latino hairstyles in 2012. The Hispanic population in New Orleans has grown by almost a quarter following Katrina and even more in surrounding parishes. Our profile link takes you to the full story. (Credit: David Gilkey/NPR) #katrina10 #neworleans

[2/3] Barber Stan Norwood (center) puts the finishing touches on a cut and style to Mike Fox's hair at the Dennis Barber Shop in Freret, a transitional neighborhood in central New Orleans. Housing prices in Freret have more than doubled in recent years and new businesses have transformed the main drag. In the years before Katrina, crime was a problem and many storefronts stood vacant. Now, the area is a prime example of New Orleans' revitalization, post-Katrina. Our profile link takes you to the full story. (Credit: David Gilkey/NPR) #katrina10 #neworleans

[1/3] Ten years after Hurricane Katrina, New Orleans today is smaller than when the storm hit, with 110,000 fewer people than the nearly half-million who had lived there. But the city's recovery is a story that varies with each neighborhood. Some neighborhoods, like the French Quarter, have seen many newcomers and now have more households than they did in 2005. Our profile link takes you to the full story. (Credit: David Gilkey/NPR) #katrina10 #neworleans

[4/4] Ruth Nunez lived in a brick home on Schnell Drive prior to Katrina. After the storm, she had her old house torn down and replaced. The new home is on stilts, with the space underneath used as a garage. Before the storm, 80 to 90 percent of the street's residents were elderly, she said. "Since Katrina," she said, "we have children all up and down the street." Our profile link takes you to the full story. (Credit: @edmundfountain for NPR) #katrina10 #neworleans

[3/4] Wilbert Landry and his son, Ronnie, moved to Schnell Drive from the 9th Ward of New Orleans in 2014. At the time of Katrina, St. Bernard Parish was an overwhelmingly white parish with a 71,000 residents. In the years immediately after the storm, less than half the population remained. But St. Bernard is growing again — it's back up to about 44,000 residents — and it's more diverse than it used to be. Our profile link takes you to the full story. (Credit: @edmundfountain for NPR) #katrina10 #neworleans

[2/4] Schnell Drive is a wide street, pockmarked with empty lots and a small cluster of homes Arabi, La., just outside of New Orleans. The community that existed a decade ago hasn't fully returned since the storm, but a few stalwarts have remained. Noney Deffes is a longtime Schnell Drive resident who survived flooding from Hurricane Katrina in a neighbor's attic. She then lived out of her recreational vehicle while rebuilding her home. Our profile link takes you to the full story. (Credit: @edmundfountain for NPR) #katrina10 #neworleans

[1/4] This is the long story of a short street: Schnell Drive, two blocks of brick homes in Arabi, La., just east of New Orleans in St. Bernard Parish. When we first visited in the fall of 2005, Donald and Colleen Bordelon were often the only two people on Schnell Drive. They had stayed in their home through the storm and the flood, and through the weeks after when the first floor was still filled with water. We documented the couple's struggles for the last ten years, including Donald's passing in 2010. Today, Colleen Bordelon still lives in the home, joined by her mother-in-law Donna. The population of the surrounding neighborhood has rebounded as some people have returned and newcomers have moved in, building new lives and even new homes amid the remnants of the old. Our profile link takes you to the full story. (Credit: @edmundfountain for NPR) #katrina10 #neworleans

Johnny Jackson fled from the rising waters of Hurricane Katrina 10 years ago and found refuge along with thousands of others at the Ernest N. Morial Convention Center in New Orleans. He is a former city councilman, state representative and then-president of the beloved local music station, WWOZ. Jackson spoke out against the poor conditions inside the convention center. Currently he is still finishing the repairs to his home, which was severely damaged during the storm. Our profile link takes you to the full story. (Credit: David Gilkey/NPR) #katrina10 #neworleans

[4/4] Beth Carey (center), walks around the park with her nieces Calysta, 15, and Jazlen, 3, in Marion, Ohio. Heroin has changed many lives in Marion. It took Chrystina Carey's life in 2013. Chrystina, Beth's twin sister, left behind two daughters. Her older daughter Calysta lives with Beth's grandmother and Beth is raising Jazlen. Our profile link takes you to the full story. (Credit: @maddiemcgarvey for NPR)

[3/4] After years of fighting her heroin addiction, Kelly Clixby's life is on more stable footing. She carries around this "Clean & Serene for Six Months" tag to represent what she has gained. Clixby has been clean since last October and now has her own apartment. Our profile link takes you to the full story. (Credit: @maddiemcgarvey for NPR)

[2/4] Police Chief Bill Collins inspects confiscated heroin in Marion, Ohio. It's been almost eight years since heroin showed up in Marion. Since then, Chief Collins says public awareness campaigns have helped with the problem. A couple of months ago his department brought down a major drug dealer.
