ASSIGNMENT! What object makes you feel manly? 
As part of All Things Considered's summer series on men in America, we want to hear about the object, tool or stuff that makes you feel manly. Here’s one from David Lee, who writes for Gumship, an online men's guide to Asian lifestyle and entertainment. He picked his Adventure Time bathrobe: "I think we're at a space in time where men are openly loving My Little Ponies, embracing cartoons, still playing video games, and we're really dictating what it means to be a man," he says. "Everyone's confused whether or not they're being ironic or not, and that's so luxurious, you know?" So tag one photo #menpr and tell us the story in the caption: who you are, your object and why it makes you feel manly. Women are also welcome!

Any photos tagged in the next 10 days are eligible to featured here on Instagram or on @NPR's website. (Photo Credit: Courtesy of Salima Koroma)

John 'Huck' Huckleberry rides home from Sterling Prison, outside Denver. After a life in jail, he is building a new life on the outside. Full story at npr.org. photo by @johnwpoole #prison #jail #penitentiary #lifebehindbars #aginginprison

ASSIGNMENT! Photography + Memory = WHA?!? So many of our memories are informed by images of moments we don’t actually remember. But they happened, right? @NPR wants to know: Do you have a #fakememory based entirely on old photos you've seen of yourself? Moments you think you remember only because you’ve seen a picture?

This one is from @as_ever_photography. Sometimes I think I remember standing on Camelback Mountain in Phoenix, wearing my Cookie Monster t-shirt and my red cowgirl outfit with white fringe, but I actually only have this memory because of this photo (a family favorite). I like to imagine my childhood favorite song, "Rhinestone Cowboy", as the soundtrack for this picture. 
Tag one photo #fakememory and tell us the story in the caption: Where are you, why, and what's special about it? (Any photos tagged in the next 10 days are eligible to featured here on Instagram or on @NPR's website.)

#shevotes @NPR wants to know: who or what first got you interested in politics? Share your memories and show us the person, thing, or event that made you pay attention or become active, using the hashtag #shevotes. Like this, from NPR's @tamarakeithnpr "This photo comes from the 1996 Hanford High School yearbook, my senior year. It shows the result of my only successful political campaign. I earned a spot as the student representative on the board of education, by securing a key endorsement, posting ridiculous fliers all over the campus and broadening the base of my voter outreach. This gave me a front row seat to some seriously divisive local politics and greatly improved the firmness of my handshake. #shevotes #npr."

This image comes to us from @karalechuga. One of her favorite things is a Chinese scroll: "I never had the privilege to know my maternal grandmother, so I know her only through her things. I'm told she bought this scroll in San Francisco while she was on the west coast building battleships for WWII. I hang it everywhere I live." Find out more about the objects in this image on @karalechuga's profile.

Thanks for all your submissions to our #PublicSquare community project with @kpcc!

This #PSMyFavoriteThings image comes to us from @erinleight. Among her prized possessions is a pin her father wore in World War II. "He quit school at 17 to join the Marines and always joked that the war would have ended much sooner if he had gotten there earlier. I lost my father a year and a half ago to lung cancer and I miss him, his humor and his strength everyday." Check out @erinleight's profile to learn more about the objects in this image.

Newscaster and reporter Paul Brown's final newscast after 30 years at NPR. "It was a career worth pursuing," he said after exiting the booth to an all-staff standing ovation. (@kainazamaria/NPR)

This #PSMyFavoriteThings image comes to us from @jenkotlewski, an expat working on an HIV research project in Zambia. Most of Jennifer's favorite things are in storage, but here are a few in her new home:

1. An 1891 original print of the constellation "Chair of Cassiopeia" reminds me that we are small and to always look up.

2. Mangos are in abundance in Zambia right now and my new favorite breakfast/lunch/dinner.

3. A "Courage" patch by @bestmadeco serves as a good reminder for a global health worker far from home.

3.  All of these things are sitting on top of a poster of "Girl before a Mirror," by Picasso. I've had a print of this painting in every bedroom and apartment since I was 13 years old, and, when I arrived at my new house in Zambia, I found the same exact one rolled up on a forgotten shelf. My favorite thing, waiting for me here.

You can learn more about the items pictured here on @jenkotlewski's profile.

It's time for another #PublicSquare project with @KPCC! Our December theme is #PSMyFavoriteThings.

Think about your life and pick the items you treasure the most or that best represent who you are. Arrange them for a photo, tell us what makes them so important in your caption and tag it #PSMyFavoriteThings.

This submission comes to us from @xxvism. Here are some of his favorite things:

1. A leather pouch that holds a lock of my father's hair. He passed away 2 years ago. If my house was burning and I could only grab one thing, this is it. 
2. An old can of Krylon spray paint. It reminds me of the countless days I spent with my best friends painting and skateboarding. The glory days!

3. A copy of the zine "Every Everything" which my brother Nick and I made for a recent show. It's a compilation of not only our creative collaborations, but also a glimpse into an unbreakable bond and friendship.

4. A railroad tie. To me this symbolizes adventure, freedom, and possibilities. It also reminds me of some beautiful lines written by Robert Frost; "I have been one acquainted with the night. I have walked out in rain -- and back in rain. I have outwalked the furthest city light." Find out more about the items in this photo on @xxvism's profile.

Hey folks! It's time for another #PublicSquare community project  with @KPCC.

December's Theme: #PSMyFavoriteThings

Think about your life and pick the items that you treasure most or best represent who you are. Arrange them for a photo, tell us what makes them so important in your caption and tag it #PSMyFavoriteThings.

And don't forget, we like stories! Tell us some good ones in the caption and we just might repost your image to @NPR or @KPCC.

This submission comes to us from @bethnakamura:

Portland, Oregon -- Beth Nakamura has a drawer set aside for all the items in this image. Here's why she holds onto all of them: 
1)A bar of Fels-Naptha soap. Because it was my mother’s favorite. She died of cancer when I was 30. Usually it’s little stuff that brings her back.

2) An anonymous booking photograph. Because behind every person is something sparkly and magnificent, a story waiting to be told. I work in journalism and see it first hand, over and over.

3) A roll of twine. Because life is, for the most part, maddeningly messy, I vacillate between wanting to stuff it all into pretty little boxes and realizing it’s just not possible. 
4) A cigarette. Because sometimes I sneak them. My dirty, shameful little secret.  Exposed.

5) A number sign. Although this No. means number, for me it will always mean: No. Period. Because my life is marked by moments that stand in defiance of that word.

6) An old snapshot holder. It’s empty. Which means it's full of possibility. Because as a photojournalist, it’s not about the pictures you've taken, but the ones you’ve yet to make.

7) Home Sweet Home, cross-stitched and framed. I made it when I longed for such things. Like most deep longing, it stays hidden from sight.

Chicago - My morning commute from near the Chicago Midway Airport into my job in the "Loop" is only a half hour. But in this timespan I witness everything from the single immigrant mom chatting away with her kid on their way to school to the first time, overpacked, Windy City visitor in awe of our rooftops and distant skyline as they approach downtown on the "L". As much as I enjoy the diversity of each passerby, my favorite part is the serenity of the evening commute. Everyone is a bit more polite, a lot less caffeinated and with only one direction: home.

Photo by @fotogramatica for our #PSCommute #PublicSquare Community Project with @KPCC.

This submission comes from  @grantslater:

Eagle Rock, Calif. - "Most people dread their Los Angeles commutes, hours of life wasted in white-knuckle freeway traffic. I don't. I commute to and from work on the 134, and it's the most beautiful urban freeway in Southern California. It crests over the foothills of the Angeles National Forest and offers sweeping views from Northeast Los Angeles to Downtown. It's amazing at sunset, which is when I took this picture of the high-tension power lines that run from Eagle Rock down into Highland Park." PROJECT RULES

October's Theme: #PSCommute

There are a few unavoidable things in life: Death, taxes and for most of us, commuting. Commutes are – by definition – routine, crowded, mundane, and a bunch of other negative adjectives.

In the next week, try to find the beauty in your daily routine. Capture it in a photo or video.

Document something beautiful during your daily trek to work and tag it #PSCommute.

In the caption please tell us:

The time of day you took the photo.

How long your commute is. 
Where you commute to and where you commute from.

This submission comes from  @shelserkin :

New York, NY -- Shel Serkin commutes from one Brooklyn neighborhood to another on the R train along 4th Avenue. He says, "New Yorkers are masters of being alone in public, and use their commute in many regenerative ways. There is an unspoken rule on the New York City subway under which fellow passengers commit to avoid eye contact, 'look, but not see' each other. As a street photographer, I break this rule every day, with my iPhone as my eye, in order to capture commuters in their most honest moments. I take pictures of them. More often than not, I give them names. This is Larissa." PROJECT RULES

The flagship store of #Printemps is located in the 9th arrondissement of #Paris, next door to #GaleriesLafayette. The expansive department store, or "grand magasin", was built in 1865 and is home to the largest beauty department in the world. I was blown away by how peaceful and stunning the view is from the terrace on the 9th floor. It's the perfect respite from the crush of shoppers below. (@beckyberger/npr)

Bravo to the ten #spinstagram sleuths who guessed #printemps! @lepetitparis @sassygrody @munnithan @dancehallhiips @alizeedg @spinellsz @zoepersina @shutupandpedal @stephanesu @_yizzh

The Höfði House, Reykjavík, Iceland – This is where the 1986 Reykjavík Summit took place, a meeting between U.S. President Ronald Reagan and Soviet leader Mikhail Gorbachev, devoted primarily to disarmament discussions. Though negotiations fell apart at the last minute, this summit was a pivotal event in the end of the Cold War, helping lay the groundwork for several arms control treaties.

Photo by @mrsgrubby for the #PSThisIsWhere visual history project with @KPCC.

This is where my mother moved my brother and I, when I was just a year older than my daughter is now. There were no curtains on the wall, the carpets were shagged and a mellow '70s green. The wallpaper was a faded pink from the original design of the house, built over a century ago. This is now where I can return with my daughter and share in all the love my mother gave me and everything she created for us.

Photo by @ohdeardrea for the #PSThisIsWhere visual history project with @KPCC.

Salt Rock (Pedra do Sal), Brazil. Yesterday, All Things Considered host Melissa Block and producers Andrea Hsu and Greg Dixon wrapped up their reporting trip to Brazil. "We went to hear samba at the Salt Rock, considered the birthplace of samba," Hsu said. "It's a steep rock where slaves once unloaded salt from ships and now it's a popular site to come listen to samba." Congrats to #spinstagram sleuth @spreadsheets who was the first to guess Pedra do Sal!

Pali Lookout, Oahu, Hawaii — This is where King Kamehameha trapped more than 400 Oahu warriors in 1795, who were then pushed (or jumped) to their deaths off the sheer 1,200-foot cliffs of Nu'uanu Pali.

Photo by @lekilihawaii for the #PSThisIsWhere visual history project with @KPCC.

Estádio do Maracanã (Maracanã Stadium) in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil. (Credit: All Things Considered Producer Andrea Hsu/@andreachupinghsu) "Estádio do Maracanã is the iconic soccer stadium where the World Cup Finals will be held in 2014," Hsu says. "It was built for the 1950 World Cup, the last time Brazil played host. That year, Brazil lost to Uruguay in the finals before a crowd of 200,000 people. Maracanã has been overhauled to the tune of $1 billion reais, or close to half a billion dollars, sparking protests among Brazilians who think the money would be better spent on health and education." Congrats to #spinstagram slueths @kylehooperpainting, @coco_perdue, @scottmbennett, @aurelianobuendia and @bensylvania who were the first five to guess Maracanã!

Savannah, Georgia -- This is where Wymberley Jones deRenne planted oak trees in 1893 at the entrance to his family's Wormsloe plantation. The land was first settled by the Jones family in 1736, and 65 acres of the original 500-acre plot still remains in the family. The rest was given to the state of Georgia as a historical site.

It's also the scene of a famous movie moment. Can you name it?

Tianducheng, a mini replica of Paris, is located in Hangzhou, China. There
are several mock European villages near where Frank Langfitt lives in Shanghai,
including an English village, Thames town and Venice. "Fake Venice," he
says, "is better done than fake Paris and [unlike fake Paris] is actually
successful." Which may explain why, according to one person he spoke to, there are 17 fake
Venices in China!

Congrats to #spinstagram sleuth @fionahhh who was the first to guess
Tianducheng!

This is where Hollywood's elite has gone for a drink since 1919.  Charlie Chaplin, Marilyn Monroe and David Lynch have all ordered from the red-coated bartenders at Musso & Frank Grill.

In the '30s, Musso's became a hangout for writers like F. Scott Fitzgerald, William Faulkner and Raymond Chandler. In later years Joseph Heller, Kurt Vonnegut and Charles Bukowski bellied up to the bar to order martinis and highballs. 
This image comes from @maeryan.

Smithville, Texas – This is where my great grandparents, Emil Dietrich Reimers and Alma Lizzie Christine Franz lived with three daughters. Emil (who I was named after) and Alma moved from Grassyville to Smithville in Texas in the winter of 1941. They bought the spot we call The Home Place with a loan from First State Bank on a handshake.

This first photo comes from photographer @andreatese.

Montauk, N.Y. – This is where Captain Frank Mundus weighed in the world's largest Great White Shark on August 6, 1986. Mundus, who is said to be the inspiration for the character Quint in Jaws, caught the 3,427 pound fish, 28 miles off Montauk and 18 miles from Block Island. It still holds the record not only for the largest shark but also for the largest fish of any kind ever caught by rod and reel.

Our last stop for #NPRDumplingWeek at D.C.'s Domku really wraps up (pun intended) the cross-cultural spirit of dumplings.

Inspired after a few years of Peace Corps in Poland, self-taught, Korean-American chef-owner Kera Carpenter makes Polish-Scandinavian food for the heart-soul. (Photo by Heather Rousseau/@hkrousseau for NPR)

Hello, Bangladesh! Here's a rooftop shot by @joshabla -- who's making a time-lapse panorama of Chittagong for Planet Money's #seedtoshirt project. 
Why are we in Bangladesh? We're trying to find out where and how our t-shirts get made, and this is just one of many stops. Guess where else!
Scott Drewno @sdrewno of The Source at his makeshift shu mai station. For #NPRDumplingWeek he showed us how to make shu mai and potstickers. 🍴 (Photo by Heather Rousseau/@hkrousseau for NPR)

After a big Kickstarter campaign, NPR's Planet Money is traveling around the world in teams with one big question: Who makes our T-shirts?

Bath, Maine -- Ben the Barber has been a fixture on Front Street in Bath for 30 years. He flew planes in service to the U.S. and now gives the citizens of Bath a reasonable haircut with a side of great story telling. A friend of his carved this likeness of Ben and gave it to him as a gift. He keeps it under glass.

Photo by @heathfish for our #PSHardWork community project with @KPCC.

Jolo, W. Va. -- Sean earned $12/hour at a small, independent mine in West Virginia. He rode in on his back, through tunnels so narrow that lying down was the only option. He spent most of his workday on his knees, shoveling coal back onto a conveyer belt, which was especially grueling with no room to stand. Sean's wife was alone with the kids most of the time. When he wasn't working, he liked to sit in their bedroom alone with his beer and painkillers and the lights off. 
Photographer Marisha Camp went back to Jolo years later and found their trailer. A neighbor told her that Sean had died and his wife had moved back to Tennessee.

Photo by @marisharocks for our #PSHardWork community project with @kpcc.

Fess up, we're all guilty of turning our cameras on ourselves. But while "selfie" is a new term, self-portraits go way back. Take for example 19th century photographer, Nadar. "He had quite an ego and a great deal of confidence" according to Judy Keller, senior curator of photographs at the Getty. Which got us thinking, what does your selfie style say about you? (Nadar/Image Courtesy of The Getty's Open Content Program, @beckyberger/NPR) #nprselfiestyle

Missoula, Mont. -- Beth Eileen Gates worked as a lunch lady in Montana for over 20 years. Her children call her home "the museum" because of all the collectibles and trinkets she has amassed. She told photographer Megan Jae Pearl that she worked hard all her life to afford the luxury of the home she has. Her husband died one year ago and now she listens to the police scanner to pass the time. #PSHardWork

Photo by @meganjaepearl.

Edinburg, Texas – Salvador Martinez, 63, has been selling newspapers at busy traffic corners for about three years. He normally works four days a week starting at 5 a.m. and working into the 100+ degree heat of the day. He buys Sunday newspapers for $1.15 sells them for $1.50. His salary is 35 cents per paper, and it all depends on how many he can sell.

Photo by @mandoalvarez.

Portland, Ore. – Katie LaRosa has been a chamber maid for 34 years, the last 12 at the Inn at the Convention Center in Portland, Ore. 
At 73, she's seen it all. "I walked in on a couple once. They thought they put the 'Do Not Disturb' sign up, but it was the maid service sign. Boy, did they get mad at me," she said, slightly harried and rushing off to the next room, cleaning cart in tow.

Photo by @bethnakamura.

Anaheim, Calif. -- Jonny is a Mickey Mouse balloon vendor at Disneyland. He's been working at the park for two years and his favorite part of the job is when people take photos of him. His least favorite? When the park is crowded and he's surrounded by people wanting balloons faster than he can get them out. That happens most of the time. Photo by @shelserkin.

Tony Chapman’s work is hard -- and hot. He’s a captain with the Oceanside, Calif., fire department and has been at it for 13 years. This year is shaping up to be the worst of his career, he says, with record numbers of fires breaking out in Southern California. Photo by @grantslater.

Public Square: A Monthly Community Project from @KPCC and @NPR

August Theme: #PSHardWork

Today, we're starting something new with our friends at @KPCC in Los Angeles. Public Square is a community storytelling project through @Instagram. Each month, we'll ask you to share a glimpse of your life or the world around you through an image or video.

Our first theme is Hard Work. Your goal is to find someone with a thankless job and thank them. We're inspired by protests among fast food workers across the country seeking pay raises. Seek out a person who makes your burger, drives your bus, checks your luggage, cleans the street or delivers your mail.

Take their portrait or capture an image of them at work. Ask them their name and their story. Write a short note about your subject in the caption.

Here's where Public Square differs from other Instagram challenges. We're public radio, and storytelling is in our DNA. For this project, your caption is always just as important as the image above it. @edkashi took this photo in Montclair, N.J. Kashi says, "Warren Green is 70 and an auto mechanic. He is also my neighbor. He's from Savannah, Ga., originally and has had the same auto repair shop in Montclair, a suburb of New York City, since 1972. For the past 42 years, he's been a fixture in this town and helped thousands of neighbors, residents and people in need of getting their cars back on the road. Always reasonable and friendly, he's a gem." PROJECT RULES • Please tag only one photo posted to Instagram from August 9th to 19th with #PSHardWork. • Any image posted with the tag in the next 10 days is eligible to featured here on Instagram, @KPCC's AudioVision and @NPR's The Picture Show.

One lovely photo fact: Ancient alchemists associated silver with the moon, and silver nitrate was thus once called "lunar caustic." All in all, this was a very cool way to learn -- hands-on -- just how far we’ve come technologically. An entire day of shooting yielded less than 10 images! 
And if YOU wanna learn more, search NPR.org for “Antietam” to see our special on Civil War wet plates with the real pro, Todd Harrington. (Photo by @clairevoyant)

The process requires a certain zen. You can easily screw up everything at any given point. So many variables can go wrong: Plate not clean enough? Start again. Spill your collodion? Start again. Expose your sensitized plate to light? Start again. To say nothing of composition, exposure and processing! (photo by @beckyberger)

This past weekend, NPR picture editors @clairevoyant and @beckyberger did some time-travel photography to learn the wet plate collodion process -- and, paradoxically, Instagrammed the process! (Photo by @clairevoyant)

I had never before seen a dragonfly like this one I spotted in Damaraland, Namibia last year.  The image jumped out at me again today, reminding me of the potted poinsettias appearing in stores and homes all over the U.S. this time of year. @johnwpoole

An Indian child receives the oral polio vaccine. Twice a year, an army of 2 million volunteers fans out across India to administer the vaccine. India has not reported a single case of polio in more than a year-and-a-half. All this week, we've been examining the world's last remaining pockets of polio, a disease for which there is no cure. (Photo by Julie McCarthy/NPR)

A nurse at the health clinic in Minjibir, Nigeria,  distributes free bed nets to combat malaria. Campaigns like this one, which offers services for malaria, attract local residents to the clinic. While they're there, residents are encouraged to get their children vaccinated against polio.  Leaders from around the world are renewing their call to eradicate polio. The disease has been eradicated in all but Pakistan, Afghanistan and Nigeria. Of those three countries, Nigeria is the only one reporting an increase this year in the number of cases of the disease.  Photo by @dpgilkey / NPR.

Two members of the Afghan Security Guards sit on a deck that overlooks the Kunar river valley from Observation Post Mustang in Kunar Province, northeastern Afghanistan. The area is used by insurgent fighters as a infiltration and smuggling route from Pakistan which is just over the mountains to the west. Photo by NPR's David Gilkey.

Performance artist Aman Mojedidi, aka Jihadi Gangsta, grew up in Jacksonville, Fla., but moved to Afghanistan in 2003 because he thought his homeland was finally on the mend. He made a name for himself in Kabul by setting up fake police checkpoints that return bribes to drivers and running a phony campaign for parliament. But now he says he's leaving Afghanistan, disappointed at the slow pace of progress.

The male Alston's mouse trills at frequencies just at the edge of human hearing. Bret Pasch, a graduate student at the University of Florida, says this type of mouse and other species can essentially sing, most likely to attract mates. "The more we search, the more we find that rodents and other small mammals produce vocalizations," he says. Photo courtesy of Pasch.

This week we're celebrating the 40th anniversary of NPR's All Things Considered. This week we're going to go retro with some pics over those 40 years. Here's our very first logo.
Crowds celebrate outside the White House after President Obama announced that Osama Bin Laden was killed in a special op in Pakistan today. Photo by Ramy Yaacoub.

The idea of being a hero doesn't really sit well with Leigh Ann Hester, so having an action figure modeled after her is, in a word, surreal. The doll is a tribute to Hester, a National Guard member awarded the Silver Star in 2005 — the only woman to win it for engaging in direct combat with the enemy. Photo by NPR’s David Gilkey.
Gaddafi Vs. Twitter. Art courtesy of Sara Fusco.
Protesters in Cairo rally in support of Libyans fighting to topple Gaddafi's regime. Photo by Gigi Ibrahim.
Libyans hold their shoes in the air in defiance while watching a speech made by Muammar Gaddafi's son. Photo courtesy of Amira Altahawi.
Two Bahraini women grieve and give thanks as protesters are allowed to return to Pearl Circle today in Manama, Bahrain. Photo by Jamal Hussein Ali.
An enormous Egyptian flag is unfurled in a sea of people at Cairo's Tahrir Square, marking one week since the departure of former president Mubarak. Photo by Gigi Ibrahim.

Three years ago, three-year-old Peng Xinle was kidnapped by child traffickers. His father, Peng Gaofeng, flooded the Chinese version of Twitter with photos and pleas for help. After three years of doing this, he finally found him, and now they've been reunited. Photo by NPR's Louisa Lim. #china #children #happyendings

Photo of Egyptian security services eating KFC near Tahrir Square, Cairo. The Tahrir Square KFC has served as a supplier of free food to protesters. Photo taken by an anonymous protester; date unknown. #Egypt #jan25
Yes, it's a Carl Kasell throw pillow.

An anti-government protester sits on a makeshiftcatapult that was installed during the height of the violence in Tahrir Square earlier this week in Cairo. Note the Facebook graffiti in the background. Photo by freelance journalist Ashraf Khalil.
Scottish man slides down 1000 feet of mountain and lives to smile about it. Scotsman 1, Mountain 0.

Here's another photo challenge, particularly for those of you experiencing winter right now: post a photo capturing what it means to be #snowbound. We'll collect your pictures through the weekend and do something cool with them next week - once we dig out of our own snow here in DC, of course.
Love vs. Hate: An NPR photography challenge.
collapsed building in downtown Port-au-Prince is gone, one of the few to have been removed. Photo by NPR’s David Gilkey.
Photo of Scott Circle from the Washington Plaza Hotel, where many NPR staff were stranded overnight due to the storm. #HDR #nofilter
Big snow storm in DC, so a posse of NPR staff are stranded near the office. At least we found a cozy hotel bar.

For tens of thousands of years on the Indonesian island of Flores, many scientists believe there lived a race of hominid that was three feet tall – now referred to as “hobbits.” What you might not know, though, is they’ve also discovered bones of a stork on Flores that was six feet tall - Leptoptilos robustus. All of this leads to a rather interesting debate – did the storks hunt the hobbits? Did the hobbits hunt the storks? Were they worshipped as gods? We may never know for sure, but at least Benjamin Arthur has drawn this picture for us to give you a sense of the scale we’re talking about.

After tonight's State of the Union address, we asked people on Twitter and Facebook to send us three words summarizing their reaction to the speech. More than 4,000 people took us up on it; here's a word cloud of the most common words submitted to us.
Nearly 70% of the country's striped bass come to the Chesapeake Bay to lay their eggs, including inlets like this one, where the Choptank and Tred Avon rivers meet. Photo by NPR’s Maggie Starbard.

There’s an article in Nat Geo’s January issue about how birds are dinosaurs and how feathers are evolutionary marvels. But the real thing to check out is the feather portraiture by photographer Robert Clark, including this pic of a king-bird of paradise feather that they shared with us. The bird has two of these wire-like feathers that wobble during display; the tail feathers are tipped with emerald green disks. #nofilter
USA Map #607, by Aaron Foster. Mixed wood, metals and paints, 2006. On display at CPB headquarters, Washington DC.

Members of the Association to Protect the Dignity of the Holy Prophet, or Tahafuz-e-Namwoos Risalat, join the Sunni Itehad Council in a protest march to denounce the Pope. The Vatican called for the abolition of Pakistan's blasphemy laws after a Christian woman accused of blaspheming the Prophet Muhammad was sentenced to death. Photo by NPR's Julie McCarthy.

Lindsey Ward dresses her 4-month-old son, Joshua, in her home in Woodbridge, Va., before making a "milk run" to receive donated breast milk from another mother. Ward believes that breast milk has greater health benefits for her son than does formula, but she is unable to pump adequate amounts of breast milk for him. Photo by Jonathan Makiri.

In this photo provided by the Library of Congress, a juvenile female Cooper's hawk is shown in the Main Reading Room in the Jefferson Building at the Library of Congress, Friday January 21, 2011 in Washington DC.

In case you haven't had enough of our coverage of the new Iron And Wine album, Sam Beam came by our office recently and performed a Tiny Desk Concert next to Bob Boilen's desk. You can find the video of his four-song acoustic set at nprmusic.org. Photo by NPR's Abby Verbosky.

Satender Sharma, 18, is a former street kid who now, as a tour guide for the Salaam Baalak Trust, leads visitors through the narrow alleys where he grew up in New Delhi. Photographed by Claire Flintoff for NPR.

In 1885, a man named Wilson A. Bentley attached a microscope to his camera and took what the Smithsonian considers the first image of a single snowflake. About eight years later, Bentley sent some 500 snowflake prints to the institution. In light of the recent snow craziness that has fallen on 49 U.S. states, Smithsonian has dug up some of these early 'flake photos for us.

Gloria Giffords (center), Rep. Gabrielle Giffords' mother, talks to her daughter on the flight to Houston. Capt. Mark Kelly (far left), the representative's husband, talks with Tracy Culbert (center right), a nurse. Photo courtesy of the office of Rep. Giffords.

A street in Havana, as photographed by Chip Cooper. Cooper, an Alabama native, is collaborating with Cuban photographer Nestor Marti for the exhibit Havana: Side By Side, displayed simultaneously in Havana and Tuscaloosa.

CC4 Nocagions, currently on display at the the Museum of Contemporary Art in Los Angeles, was conceived in 1973 by Brazilian artists Helio Oiticica and Neville D'Almeida. Visitors are invited to swim in the pool, and the museum even sells $16 disposable bathing suits in case you've come unprepared. Photo by Iwan Baan.

Judy Jones Petersen looks at a treasured photo of her family. Her brother, Dean Jones, was killed in the coal mine explosion last year in West Virginia that left 29 mine workers dead. Photo by NPR's Howard Berkes.

Science writer Sam Kean, in his book The Disappearing Spoon, worked really hard to find the longest word in English. After much sleuthing, he landed on a word that comes not from dancing English nannies but from virus-hunting scientists. It's a protein found in the tobacco mosaic virus. But does that make it an actual word in English?

In this photo provided by the office of Rep Gabrielle Giffords, her husband, Mark Kelly, stands with Giffords as she looks from her bed at the Santa Catalina Mountains while on an outdoor deck at University Medical Center in Tucson, Arizona.
Weird Al, apparently imitating The Scream while singing.
Two Deer And A View
Meeting up with @Kevin of Instagram
More NPR office decor

When it was finished in the mid-1960s by the Soviet Union, the Salang Tunnel between Kabul and Mazar-e-Sharif was hailed as an engineering marvel – and at 11,154 feet in altitude was the highest road tunnel in the world at that time,. Today it is dusty, unpaved, claustrophobic, unlit in parts, and potholed. Regardless, it’s a vital link that connects the north with the rest of the country. Photo by NPR’s Nishant Dahiya.
Meet "Prudence," Sipsmith's handmade, copper-pot still. They're the makers of London Dry Gin. It's the first copper gin still to be licensed in London since 1820. Photo for NPR by Katie Bilboa.

Women at the Wangjia mosque in Kaifeng, China, work early in the morning in the kitchen. The mosques began as Quranic schools for girls in the late 17th century. They were the only places girls could receive an education; now, they also serve as community centers. Photo by Ariana Lindquist for NPR.

Despite its socialist roots, Egypt is now primarily a free-market economy with some state control. Here, a belt salesman carries his product around the market in the Ataba district of Cairo. Photo by Holly Pickett for NPR.
Alpha Company's 1st Sgt. Kenneth Bolin, of the 101st Airborne Division, watches a resupply helicopter circle overhead on the Afghanistan-Pakistan border. Photo by NPR’s David Gilkey.

In a Tucson hospital room, Mark Kelly keeps vigil beside his wife, Rep. Gabrielle Giffords, as she undergoes treatment for severe head injuries in this photo taken Sunday and released late Tuesday. Photo courtesy of the office of Rep. Giffords.

Spc. Jotiyar Saaty, with Bravo Company of the 101st Airborne Division, yells for more ammunition while trying to suppress heavy enemy fire near a village in the Pashmul area of Kandahar province. Photo by NPR’s David Gilkey.

A Toyota Sienna minivan has been bulletproofed in a Mexico City shop that retrofits vehicles with armor. The glass in the door window is considerably thicker than in regular car windows. Photo by NPR’s Jason Beaubien.

A Hubble telescope image – unaltered by IG filters - of Hanny's Voorwerp, an extraordinary interstellar green blob of gas, 300,000 light-years across. It glows because a quasar is shooting its laser-like energy beam across an entire galaxy into the blob, causing it to glow that Incredible-Hulk green. Really puts the laser pointer I use to play with my cat in perspective. Photo courtesy of NASA. - @acarvin
Suspicious-looking birds gathering on NPR's rooftop deck. Snow must be comin'.  Yes indeed.

In China, Mazu, a folk goddess of the sea, has an estimated 160 million followers and 4,000 temples devoted to her. Cheng Zhigui, 23, is dressed to perform in a traditional opera during celebrations for Mazu's 1050th birthday on Meizhou Island in the southern province of Fujian. "We perform for Mazu. We believe she's watching us sing opera. Even if nobody came, she'd still be watching us," he says. Photo by Ariana Lindquist for NPR.
Haitian children play in front of latrines built by the American Red Cross at an encampment for survivors of the 2010 earthquake, near Cite Soleil. Photo by Valentina Pasquali for NPR.

Valentino Achak Deng was separated from his family for 17 years during Sudan's brutal civil war. One of Sudan's Lost Boys, Deng now has returned to his homeland and runs a school. Photographed by NPR's Frank Langfitt.
NPR HQ at dusk
Ballake Cissoko and Vincent Segal playing kora and cello, respectively, for an NPR Music Tiny Desk Concert. Cissoko has a new album coming out this week with Toumani Diabate.
Soldiers from the Army's 101st Airborne Division walk along high mud walls in a village in Afghanistan's Kandahar province. Photo by NPR’s David Gilkey.
Photo by @digiphile of tonight's Capitol Hill rally for Rep. Gabby Giffords and the other victims of the mass shooting in Tucson, Arizona earlier today.
A crew of men construct frames for improvised classrooms to replace a Port-au-Prince school that collapsed after the Haitian earthquake. Photo by NPR's David Gilkey.
NPR's Scott Simon being a good sport, as captured by @emersonebrown.
The picture says it all.
Southern Sudan's University of Juba is the region's leading school, but facilities — like this dorm — are decrepit. Photo by NPR’s Frank Langfitt.
NPR office decor, as captured by @jen2e.
Sam Beam of Iron And Wine is at our office and is playing some songs for us. We're recording it as a Tiny Desk Concert.

Immigrants like these Indians at a Sikh festival in Barcelona are bolstering Europe’s stagnant population growth rates. Research shows that the more education a woman receives, the fewer children she is likely to have. Photo by Randy Olson, courtesy of National Geographic.
Maliha, a Bedouin mother of four, at her home in Nuweiba, Sinai Peninsula, Egypt. Photo by Holly Pickett for NPR.
Talk of the Nation exec producer Sue Goodwin welcomes the audience for our Nat Geo broadcast.
NPR's Neal Conan and explorer Bob Ballard talking after today's live show at Nat Geo.
Neal Conan getting ready for a live Talk Of The Nation broadcast at Nat Geo. We go live at 2pm ET.
“We may be dissatisfied, but we still need to eat," says Xu Shengru, buying cabbage — which she says has doubled in price — at a Beijing market. Photo by NPR’s Louisa Lim.
You gotta love a guy who gets an NPR tat on his shoulder. Well, we do.

Pamela Omiyo, who sells dresses and suits in the Nairobi slum of Kibera, says that the mobile money transfer system M-PESA has helped triple her business in recent years. It used to take days for her to send and receive payment for fabric and dresses. Now, it's instantaneous on her mobile phone. Photo by NPR’s East Africa correspondent, Frank Langfitt.
Iron And Wine on stage in NYC for a live premiere of their upcoming album, streamed by WNYC and NPR Music. Photo courtesy of NPR alum @mgallivan.

Smørrebrød, the Danish word for "butter bread," includes countless open-face sandwich combinations, from minimal to lavish. How they are assembled varies with the occasion. However, they share a specific preparation method and order in which they are eaten. They also share ingredients that reflect straightforward Scandinavian sensibilities, using simple, honest, local food attractively presented with little waste. Photo for NPR by Lynda Balslev.

A woman walks through a tent city outside the Haitian capital, Port-au-Prince. Nearly a year after a devastating earthquake killed more than 200,000 people and destroyed Port-Au-Prince, more than 1.5 million people remain homeless amid a challenging and slow recovery process. Photo by NPR’s David Gilkey.

Visitors tour the galleries of The Phillips Collection in Washington, D.C. Duncan Phillips founded the museum 90 years ago as a way to memorialize his father and brother — and, says his great-niece, "to stimulate his love of life and ideas and thinking." Photo by Max Hirshfeld.

Reynaldo Dagsa, a Philippine politician, shot a photo of his family standing by a car. Little did he know that also in the photo was an assassin preparing to shoot him. He died soon after the photo was taken; the gunman and an accomplice have since been arrested.

Located near Evansville, Indiana, the Mann Hopewell Site boasts around 20 mounds built by the Hopewell Tradition, a culture that flourished in the Eastern and Midwestern U.S. nearly 2,000 years ago. Photo by Micah Schweitzer for NPR.
A self-portrait by Steve Duncan in New York City’s Croton Aqueduct. Duncan is an “urban mole” – someone who explores the hidden infrastructure of major cities.

The elephant has fallen on tough times in Thailand. Over the past 20 years, elephants and their owners have drifted into cities to beg after a ban on logging left them unemployed. Now, one ethnic group renowned for its "elephant masters," the Kui people, is helping to coax the animals back to the country. Photo by Wang Zemin for NPR.

Abigail Washburn plays bluegrass influenced by Chinese folk music. It’d make the perfect soundtrack to the HBO series Deadwood; in fact you can almost hear the show in her work. Here’s a pic of her performing in our offices. You can watch the video at npr.org/tinydeskconcerts.
View of DC, looking north from NPR's roof

RIP, Pete Postlethwaite. You were a great actor, and you served Keyser Söze well in The Usual Suspects. He died yesterday at age 64, after a long battle with cancer. Photo: Fergus McDonald/Getty Images.

First-grader Katie Oliver at her doctor’s office in Baltimore. Katie, who has autism, is going through chelation therapy for lead poisoning. Kids who put a lot of objects in their mouths, such as kids with developmental disabilities, are at a higher risk for lead poisoning. Photographed for NPR by Maggie Starbard. http://n.pr/ep7bWs

This is what researchers at the ATLAS detector at CERN's Hadron Collider expect data from a Higgs boson to look like. The Higgs boson is the subatomic particle that scientists say gives everything in the universe mass. We'll have a story about it on Weekend All Things Considered this afternoon.
Aaron Neville revisits the house where he spent his teen years in uptown New Orleans. Photographed by NPR's Debbie Elliott.
Wafaa Bilal implanted a webcam in the back of his head. The camera is taking a picture a minute for a year, and the images are being streamed live at Mathaf, the Arab Museum of Modern Art.

Mussarat Ahmed Zeb, 49, a princess of Swat's former royal family, is on a mission to revive the heritage of Pakistan's Swat Valley "one stitch at a time." When the Taliban started terrorizing the valley, Ahmed Zeb started training hundreds of women in the dying art of Swati embroidery. The electrifying colors and distinct designs are a legacy of this once princely state. Photo by NPR Pakistan correspondent Julie McCarthy.
